interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-d-8-iii-Interp-2-i-F
interpParagraph.content: The property is taken through eminent domain.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-d-8-iii-Interp-2-i-G
interpParagraph.content: A prior lienholder forecloses.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-d-8-iii-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: By contrast, the filing of a judgment against the consumer would permit termination and acceleration only if the amount of the judgment and collateral subject to the judgment is such that the creditor's security is adversely affected. If the consumer commits waste or otherwise destructively uses or fails to maintain the property such that the action adversely affects the security, the loan may be terminated and the balance accelerated. Illegal use of the property by the consumer would permit termination and acceleration if it subjects the property to seizure. If one of two consumers obligated on a loan dies, the creditor may terminate the loan and accelerate the balance if the security is adversely affected. If the consumer moves out of the dwelling that secures the loan and that action adversely affects the security, the creditor may terminate a loan and accelerate the balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi
paragraph.content: For which the ratio of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt to total monthly income at the time of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> does not exceed 43 percent. For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2-vi" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(vi)</ref>, the ratio of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt to total monthly income is determined:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-A
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2-vi-B" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(vi)(B)</ref> of this section, in accordance with the standards in appendix <ref target="1026-Q" reftype="internal">Q</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B
paragraph.content: Using the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payment on:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B-1
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>, including the monthly payment for <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref>, in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2-iv" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(iv)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B-2
paragraph.content: Any <ref target="1026-43-b-12" reftype="term">simultaneous loan</ref> that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> knows or has reason to know will be made, in accordance with paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-c-2-iv" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(iv)</ref> and <ref target="1026-43-c-6" reftype="internal">(c)(6)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1-a
paragraph.content: An “S” corporation is generally a small, start-up business, with gains and losses passed to stockholders in proportion to each stockholder's percentage of business ownership.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1-b
paragraph.content: Income for owners of “S” corporations comes from IRS Form W-2 wages, and is taxed at the individual rate. The IRS Form 1120S, <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">Compensation</ref> of Officers line item is transferred to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s individual IRS Form 1040.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Income or assets relied on. A creditor need consider, and therefore need verify, only the income or assets the creditor relies on to evaluate the consumer's repayment ability. See comment 43(c)(2)(i)-2. For example, if a consumer's application states that the consumer earns a salary and is paid an annual bonus and the creditor relies on only the consumer's salary to evaluate the consumer's repayment ability, the creditor need verify only the salary. See also comments 43(c)(3)-1 and -2.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Multiple applicants. If multiple consumers jointly apply for a loan and each lists income or assets on the application, the creditor need verify only the income or assets the creditor relies on in determining repayment ability. See comment 43(c)(2)(i)-5.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-iii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: General. For purposes of the repayment ability determination required under § 1026.43(c)(2), a creditor must consider the consumer's monthly payment on a covered transaction that is calculated as required under § 1026.43(c)(5).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-C-Interp-3-i-C
interpParagraph.content: For purposes of § 1026.43(c)(2)(iii), the creditor must determine the consumer's ability to repay the loan based on a monthly payment of $1,716, which is the substantially equal, monthly payment of principal and interest that will repay the maximum loan amount of $229,251 over the remaining loan term of 333 months using the fully indexed rate of 8 percent. See comments 43(b)(7)-1 and -2 discussing the calculation of the maximum loan amount, and § 1026.43(b)(11) for the meaning of the term “recast.”

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-p7
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must obtain a complete copy of the current awards letter. ii. Not all Social Security income is for retirement-aged recipients; therefore, documented continuation is required. iii. Some portion of Social Security income may be “grossed up” if deemed nontaxable by the IRS. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3
paragraph.title: Escrows
paragraph.content: Cancellation—

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i
paragraph.title: Failure to escrow for property taxes and insurance.
paragraph.content: General. Except as provided in paragraph (b)(3)(ii) of this section, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or s<ref target="1026-35-b-3-ii" reftype="internal">ervicer ma</ref>y cancel an escrow account required in paragraph (b)(1) of this section only upon the earlier of:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i-A
paragraph.content: Termination of the underlying debt obligation; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i-B
paragraph.content: Receipt no earlier than five years after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> of a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s request to cancel the escrow account.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii
paragraph.title: Exemptions for loans secured by shares in a cooperative and for certain condominium units.
paragraph.content: Delayed cancellation. Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(3)(i) of this section, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or servicer shall not cancel an escrow account pursuant to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s request described in paragraph (b)(3)(i)(B) of this section unless the following conditions are satisfied:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii-A
paragraph.content: The unpaid principal balance is less than 80 percent of the original value of the property securing the underlying debt obligation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii-B
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> currently is not delinquent o<ref target="1026-35-b-3-i" reftype="internal">r in defa</ref>ult on the underlying debt obligation.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C-Interp-1-ii-A
interpParagraph.content: General. Under § 1026.32(b)(1)(i)(C)(2), private mortgage insurance premiums payable at or before consummation (i.e., single or up-front premiums) may be excluded from points and fees, even though they are included in the finance charge under § 1026.4(a) and (b). However, the portion of the premium that exceeds the amount payable under policies in effect at the time of origination under section 203(c)(2)(A) of the National Housing Act (12 U.S.C. 1709(c)(2)(A)) is included in points and fees. To determine whether any portion of the premium exceeds the amount payable under policies in effect at the time of origination under section 203(c)(2)(A) of the National Housing Act, a creditor references the premium amount that would be payable for the transaction under that Act, as implemented by applicable regulations and other written authorities issued by the Federal Housing Administration (such as Mortgagee Letters), even if the transaction would not qualify to be insured under that Act (including, for example, because the principal amount exceeds the maximum insurable under that Act).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C-Interp-1-ii-B
interpParagraph.content: Non-refundable premiums. To qualify for the exclusion from points and fees, private mortgage insurance premiums payable at or before consummation must be required to be refunded on a pro rata basis and the refund must be automatically issued upon notification of the satisfaction of the underlying mortgage loan.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C-Interp-1-ii-C
interpParagraph.content: Example. Assume that a $3,000 private mortgage insurance premium charged on a closed-end mortgage loan is payable at or before closing and is required to be refunded on a pro rata basis and that the refund is automatically issued upon notification of the satisfaction of the underlying mortgage loan. Assume also that the maximum premium allowable under the National Housing Act is $2,000. In this case, the creditor could exclude $2,000 from points and fees but would have to include the $1,000 that exceeds the allowable premium under the National Housing Act. However, if the $3,000 private mortgage insurance premium were not required to be refunded on a pro rata basis or if the refund were not automatically issued upon notification of the satisfaction of the underlying mortgage loan, the entire $3,000 premium would be included in points and fees.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-3-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Discounted and premium adjustable-rate transactions. In some adjustable-rate transactions, creditors may set an initial interest rate that is not determined by the index or formula used to make later interest rate adjustments. In some cases, the initial rate charged to consumers is lower than the rate would be if it were calculated using the index or formula that will apply after recast, as determined at consummation (i.e., a “discounted rate”). In other cases, the initial rate may be higher (i.e., a “premium rate”). For purposes of determining the fully indexed rate where the initial interest rate is not determined using the index or formula for subsequent interest rate adjustments, the creditor must use the interest rate that would have applied had the creditor used such index or formula plus margin at the time of consummation. That is, in determining the fully indexed rate, the creditor must not take into account any discounted or premium rate. To illustrate, assume an adjustable-rate transaction where the initial interest rate is not based on an index or formula, or is based on an index or formula that will not apply after recast, and is set at 5 percent for the first five years. The loan agreement provides that future interest rate adjustments will be calculated based on a specific index plus a 3 percent margin. If the value of the index at consummation is 5 percent, the interest rate that would have been applied at consummation had the creditor based the initial rate on this index is 8 percent (5 percent plus 3 percent margin). For purposes of § 1026.43(b)(3), the fully indexed rate is 8 percent. For discussion of payment calculations based on the greater of the fully indexed rate or premium rate for purposes of the repayment ability determination under § 1026.43(c), see § 1026.43(c)(5)(i) and comment 43(c)(5)(i)-2.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-ii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Example. Under § 1026.43(f)(1)(ii), if a qualified mortgage provides for a balloon payment, the creditor must determine that the consumer is able to make all scheduled payments under the legal obligation other than the balloon payment. For example, assume a loan in an amount of $200,000 that has a five-year loan term, but is amortized over 30 years. The loan agreement provides for a fixed interest rate of 6 percent. The loan consummates on March 3, 2014, and the monthly payment of principal and interest scheduled for the first five years is $1,199, with the first monthly payment due on April 1, 2014. The balloon payment of $187,308 is required on the due date of the 60th monthly payment, which is April 1, 2019. The loan can be a qualified mortgage if the creditor underwrites the loan using the scheduled principal and interest payment of $1,199, plus the consumer's monthly payment for all mortgage-related obligations, and satisfies the other criteria set forth in § 1026.43(f).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-ii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Creditor's determination. A creditor must determine that the consumer is able to make all scheduled payments other than the balloon payment to satisfy § 1026.43(f)(1)(ii), in accordance with the legal obligation, together with the consumer's monthly payments for all mortgage-related obligations and excluding the balloon payment, to meet the repayment ability requirements of § 1026.43(f)(1)(ii). A creditor satisfies § 1026.43(f)(1)(ii) if it uses the maximum payment in the payment schedule, excluding any balloon payment, to determine if the consumer has the ability to make the scheduled payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii
paragraph.content: Establish by agreement that the mortgage broker must present the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> an alternative <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> without a <ref target="1026-43-b-10" reftype="term">prepayment penalty</ref> that satisfies the requirements of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-g-3" reftype="internal">(g)(3)</ref> of this section, offered by:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Another <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, if the transaction offered by the other <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> has a lower interest rate or a lower total dollar amount of discount points and origination points or fees.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Sample determination of allowable points and fees.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-i
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $105,000 falls into the first points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of 3 percent of the total loan amount applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(A). Therefore, if the calculation under comment 32(b)(4)(i)-1 results in a total loan amount of $102,000, then the allowable total points and fees for this loan are 3 percent of $102,000, or $3,060.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-ii
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $75,000 falls into the second points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of $3,000 applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(B). The allowable total points and fees for this loan are $3,000, regardless of the total loan amount.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-iii
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $50,000 falls into the third points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of 5 percent of the total loan amount applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(C). Therefore, if the calculation under comment 32(b)(4)(i)-1 results in a total loan amount of $48,000, then the allowable total points and fees for this loan are 5 percent of $48,000, or $2,400.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-iv
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $15,000 falls into the fourth points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of $1,000 applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(D). The allowable total points and fees for this loan are $1,000, regardless of the total loan amount.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-v
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $10,000 falls into the fifth points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of 8 percent of the total loan amount applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(E). Therefore, if the calculation under comment 32(b)(4)(i)-1 results in a total loan amount of $7,000, then the allowable total points and fees for this loan are 8 percent of $7,000, or $560.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-1-Interp-1-ii-A-1
interpParagraph.content: The consumer demonstrated actual ability to repay the loan by making timely payments, without modification or accommodation, for a significant period of time after consummation or, for an adjustable-rate, interest-only, or negative-amortization mortgage, for a significant period of time after recast;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-D-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Real estate-related fees. The exclusion for bona fide third-party charges not retained by the creditor, loan originator, or an affiliate of either is limited by § 1026.32(b)(1)(iii) in the general definition of points and fees. Section 1026.32(b)(1)(iii) requires inclusion in points and fees of items listed in § 1026.4(c)(7) unless the charge is reasonable, the creditor receives no direct or indirect compensation in connection with the charge, and the charge is not paid to an affiliate of the creditor. If a charge is required to be included in points and fees under § 1026.32(b)(1)(iii), it may not be excluded under § 1026.32(b)(1)(i)(D), even if the criteria for exclusion in § 1026.32(b)(1)(i)(D) are satisfied.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i
paragraph.title: General rule.
paragraph.content: General rule. Except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-5-ii" reftype="internal">(c)(5)(ii)</ref> of this section, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must make the consideration required under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-iii" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(iii)</ref> of this section using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i-A
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-43-b-3" reftype="term">fully indexed rate</ref> or any introductory interest rate, whichever is greater; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i-B
paragraph.content: Monthly, <ref target="1026-43-b-2" reftype="term">fully amortizing payments</ref> that are substantially equal.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-p9
paragraph.content: ```note Note:A tax transcript obtained directly from the IRS may be used in lieu of signed tax returns, and the cost of the transcript may be charged to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. ```

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-Interp-7-v-A
interpParagraph.content: A loan in an amount of $200,000 has a 30-year loan term. The loan agreement provides that the interest rate is 6.5 percent for the first two years of the loan, 7 percent for the next three years, and then 7.5 percent for remainder of the loan term. The maximum interest rate during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due is 7.5 percent, which occurs on the due date of the 60th monthly payment. The outstanding principal balance at the end of the fifth year (after the 60th payment is credited) is $187,868.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-3-Interp-5-ii
interpParagraph.content: Assume a fixed-rate mortgage with an interest rate at consummation of 7 percent that is fixed for the 30-year loan term. For purposes of this section, the maximum interest rate that may apply during the loan term is 7 percent, which is the interest rate that is fixed at consummation. “Fixed-rate mortgage” is defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iii).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-D-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Charges not retained by the creditor, loan originator, or an affiliate of either. In general, a creditor is not required to count in points and fees any bona fide third-party charge not retained by the creditor, loan originator, or an affiliate of either. For example, if bona fide charges are imposed by a third-party settlement agent and are not retained by the creditor, loan originator, or an affiliate of either, those charges are not included in points and fees, even if those charges are included in the finance charge under § 1026.4(a)(2). The term loan originator has the same meaning as in § 1026.36(a)(1).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-3-Interp-5-i
interpParagraph.content: Assume a step-rate mortgage with an interest rate fixed at 6.5 percent for the first two years of the loan, 7 percent for the next three years, and 7.5 percent thereafter for the remainder of loan term. For purposes of this section, the creditor must use 7.5 percent, which is the maximum rate that may apply during the loan term. “Step-rate mortgage” is defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(ii).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-ii-A
paragraph.title: Monthly debt-to-income ratio.
paragraph.content: Monthly debt-to-income ratio. If a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> considers the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly debt-to-income ratio under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-vii" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(vii)</ref> of this section, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must consider the ratio of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt obligations to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-p16
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The tax-exempt nature of some of the above payments should also be considered. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-ii-B
paragraph.title: Monthly residual income.
paragraph.content: Monthly residual income. If a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> considers the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly residual income under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-vii" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(vii)</ref> of this section, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must consider the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s remaining income after subtracting the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt obligations from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2
paragraph.title: VA Benefits.
paragraph.content: VA Benefits.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-a
paragraph.content: Direct <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> for service-related disabilities from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives documentation from the VA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-b
paragraph.content: Education benefits used to offset education expenses are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3
paragraph.title: Government Assistance Programs.
paragraph.content: Government Assistance Programs.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-a
paragraph.content: Income received from government assistance programs is acceptable as long as the paying agency provides documentation indicating that the income is expected to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-b
paragraph.content: If the income from government assistance programs will not be received for at least three years, it may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-c
paragraph.content: Unemployment income must be documented for two years, and there must be reasonable assurance that this income will continue. This requirement may apply to seasonal employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-c
paragraph.content: Income must also be reduced proportionately by the total obligations payable by the partnership in less than one year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-b
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must review IRS Form 1065 to assess the viability of the business. Both depreciation and depletion may be added back to the income in proportion to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s share of income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-d
paragraph.content: Important: Cash withdrawals from the partnership may have a severe negative impact on the partnership's ability to continue operating, and must be considered in the income analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4
paragraph.title: Mortgage Credit Certificates.
paragraph.content: Mortgage <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">Credit</ref> Certificates.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4-a
paragraph.content: If a government entity subsidizes the mortgage payments either through direct payments or tax rebates, these payments may be considered as acceptable income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4-b
paragraph.content: Either type of subsidy may be added to gross income, or used directly to offset the mortgage payment, before calculating the qualifying ratios.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5
paragraph.title: Homeownership Subsidies.
paragraph.content: Homeownership Subsidies.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-a
paragraph.content: A monthly subsidy may be treated as income, if a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is receiving subsidies under the housing choice voucher home ownership option from a public housing agency (PHA). Although continuation of the homeownership voucher subsidy beyond the first year is subject to Congressional appropriation, for the purposes of underwriting, the subsidy will be assumed to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-b
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is receiving the subsidy directly, the amount received is treated as income. The amount received may also be treated as nontaxable income and be “grossed up” by 25 percent, which means that the amount of the subsidy, plus 25 percent of that subsidy may be added to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income from employment and/or other sources.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-c
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditors</ref> may treat this subsidy as an “offset” to the monthly mortgage payment (that is, reduce the monthly mortgage payment by the amount of the home ownership assistance payment before dividing by the monthly income to determine the payment-to-income and debt-to-income ratios). The subsidy payment must not pass through the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s hands.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d
paragraph.content: The assistance payment must be:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-i
paragraph.content: Paid directly to the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-ii
paragraph.content: Placed in an account that only the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may access.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-p17
paragraph.content: ```note Note:Assistance payments made directly to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must be treated as income. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1-b
paragraph.content: Each partner pays taxes on his/her proportionate share of the partnership's net income.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iii-C
paragraph.content: The charge is not paid to an <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1-a
paragraph.content: A partnership is formed when two or more individuals form a business, and share in profits, losses, and responsibility for running the company.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i
paragraph.title: Non-standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Non-standard mortgage. The term non-standard mortgage means a <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> that is:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-A
paragraph.content: An adjustable-rate mortgage, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-7-i" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(7)(i)</ref>, with an introductory fixed interest rate for a period of one year or longer;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-B
paragraph.content: An interest-only loan, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-7-iv" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(7)(iv)</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-C
paragraph.content: A negative amortization loan, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-7-v" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(7)(v)</ref>.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10
interpParagraph.content: Example of payment calculation for a negative amortization loan if payments above minimum amount made. The following example illustrates the rule described in comment 43(d)(5)(i)-8:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-i
interpParagraph.content: A loan in an amount of $200,000 has a 30-year loan term. The loan agreement provides that the consumer can make minimum monthly payments that cover only part of the interest accrued each month until the date on which the principal balance increases to the negative amortization cap of 115 percent of the loan amount, or for the first five years of monthly payments (60 payments), whichever occurs first. The loan is an adjustable-rate mortgage that adjusts monthly according to a specified index plus a margin of 3.5 percent. The introductory interest rate at consummation is 1.5 percent. One month after consummation, the interest rate adjusts and will adjust monthly thereafter based on the specified index plus a margin of 3.5 percent. The maximum lifetime interest rate is 10.5 percent; there are no other periodic interest rate adjustment caps that limit how quickly the maximum lifetime rate may be reached. The minimum monthly payment for the first year is based on the initial interest rate of 1.5 percent. After that, the minimum monthly payment adjusts annually, but may increase by no more than 7.5 percent over the previous year's payment. The minimum monthly payment is $690 in the first year, $742 in the second year, $798 in the third year, $857 in the fourth year, and $922 in the fifth year.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-ii
interpParagraph.content: The non-standard mortgage is consummated on February 15, 2014, and the first monthly payment is due on April 1, 2014. Assume that the consumer has made more than the minimum periodic payments, and that after the consumer's 12th monthly on-time payment the outstanding principal balance is $195,000. Based on the calculation of the maximum loan amount after adjusting for this outstanding principal balance, the negative amortization cap of 115 percent would be reached on March 1, 2019, the due date of the 60th monthly payment.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-iii
interpParagraph.content: On March 15, 2015, the creditor receives the consumer's written application for a refinancing, after the consumer has made 12 monthly on-time payments. On this date, the index value is 4.5 percent.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-iv
interpParagraph.content: To calculate the non-standard mortgage payment that must be compared to the standard mortgage payment under § 1026.43(d)(2)(ii), the creditor must use:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-iv-A
interpParagraph.content: The maximum loan amount of $229,219 as of March 1, 2019.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-iv-B
interpParagraph.content: The fully indexed rate of 8 percent, which is the index value of 4.5 percent as of March 15, 2015 (the date on which the creditor receives the application for a refinancing) plus the margin of 3.5 percent.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-iv-C
interpParagraph.content: The remaining loan term as of March 1, 2019, the date of the recast, which is exactly 25 years (300 monthly payments).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-v
interpParagraph.content: Based on these assumptions, the monthly payment for the non-standard mortgage for purposes of determining whether the standard mortgage monthly payment is lower than the non-standard mortgage monthly payment (see § 1026.43(d)(2)(ii)) is $1,769. This is the substantially equal, monthly payment of principal and interest required to repay the maximum loan amount at the fully indexed rate over the remaining term.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-iii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Creditor's records. Section 1026.43(b)(13)(iii) provides that a third-party record includes a record the creditor maintains for an account of the consumer held by the creditor. Examples of such accounts include checking accounts, savings accounts, and retirement accounts. Examples of such accounts also include accounts related to a consumer's outstanding obligations to a creditor. For example, a third-party record includes the creditor's records for a first-lien mortgage to a consumer who applies for a subordinate-lien home equity loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-i
paragraph.content: Reduce the gross rental amount by 25 percent for vacancies and maintenance;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-3-ii
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-8-Interp-3-i
interpParagraph.content: If a creditor does not require earthquake insurance to be obtained in connection with the mortgage loan, but the consumer voluntarily chooses to purchase such insurance, the earthquake insurance premium is not a mortgage-related obligation for purposes of § 1026.43(b)(8).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-8-ii
interpParagraph.content: Second, the calculation must be based on substantially equal monthly payments of principal and interest that will fully repay the maximum loan amount over the term of the loan remaining as of the date the loan is recast. For example, if the loan term is 30 years and the loan is recast on the due date of the 60th monthly payment, the creditor must assume a remaining loan term of 25 years (300 monthly payments).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii-Interp
interpParagraph.title: 43(e)(1)(ii) Presumption of compliance for higher-priced covered transactions.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: General. Under § 1026.43(e)(1)(ii), a creditor or assignee of a qualified mortgage under § 1026.43(e)(2), (e)(4), or (f) that is a higher-priced covered transaction is presumed to comply with the repayment ability requirements of § 1026.43(c). To rebut the presumption, it must be proven that, despite meeting the standards for a qualified mortgage (including either the debt-to-income standard in § 1026.43(e)(2)(vi) or the standards of one of the entities specified in § 1026.43(e)(4)(ii)), the creditor did not have a reasonable and good faith belief in the consumer's repayment ability. Specifically, it must be proven that, at the time of consummation, based on the information available to the creditor, the consumer's income, debt obligations, alimony, child support, and the consumer's monthly payment (including mortgage-related obligations) on the covered transaction and on any simultaneous loans of which the creditor was aware at consummation would leave the consumer with insufficient residual income or assets other than the value of the dwelling (including any real property attached to the dwelling) that secures the loan with which to meet living expenses, including any recurring and material non-debt obligations of which the creditor was aware at the time of consummation, and that the creditor thereby did not make a reasonable and good faith determination of the consumer's repayment ability. For example, a consumer may rebut the presumption with evidence demonstrating that the consumer's residual income was insufficient to meet living expenses, such as food, clothing, gasoline, and health care, including the payment of recurring medical expenses of which the creditor was aware at the time of consummation, and after taking into account the consumer's assets other than the value of the dwelling securing the loan, such as a savings account. In addition, the longer the period of time that the consumer has demonstrated actual ability to repay the loan by making timely payments, without modification or accommodation, after consummation or, for an adjustable-rate mortgage, after recast, the less likely the consumer will be able to rebut the presumption based on insufficient residual income and prove that, at the time the loan was made, the creditor failed to make a reasonable and good faith determination that the consumer had the reasonable ability to repay the loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-a
paragraph.content: Both general and limited partnerships report income on IRS Form 1065, and the partners' share of income is carried over to Schedule E of IRS Form 1040.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-iii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Creditor's records. Section 1026.43(b)(13)(iii) provides that a third-party record includes a record the creditor maintains for an account of the consumer held by the creditor. Examples of such accounts include checking accounts, savings accounts, and retirement accounts. Examples of such accounts also include accounts related to a consumer's outstanding obligations to a creditor. For example, a third-party record includes the creditor's records for a first-lien mortgage to a consumer who applies for a subordinate-lien home equity loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-6-ii
paragraph.content: A home equity line of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-40" reftype="internal">1026.40</ref>, by using the periodic payment required under the terms of the plan and the amount of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> to be drawn at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> of the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-ii
paragraph.content: Has the same <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref> as the <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref> for the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> with a <ref target="1026-43-b-10" reftype="term">prepayment penalty</ref>;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Alternative to creditor's offer. Section 1026.43(g)(4)(ii) requires that the creditor provide, by agreement, for the mortgage broker to present the consumer an alternative covered transaction that satisfies the requirements of § 1026.43(g)(3) offered by either the creditor or by another creditor, if the other creditor offers a covered transaction with a lower interest rate or a lower total dollar amount of discount points and origination points or fees. The agreement may provide for the mortgage broker to present both the creditor's covered transaction and an alternative covered transaction offered by another creditor with a lower interest rate or a lower total dollar amount of origination discount points and points or fees. See comment 36(e)(3)-3 for guidance in determining which step-rate mortgage has a lower interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1
paragraph.title: Military Income.
paragraph.content: Military Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a
paragraph.content: Military personnel not only receive base pay, butoftentimes are entitled to additional forms of pay, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-i
paragraph.content: Income from variable housing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: Clothing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: Flight or hazard pay;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iv
paragraph.content: Rations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-v
paragraph.content: Proficiency pay.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-b
paragraph.content: These types of additional pay are acceptable when analyzing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income as long as the probability of such pay to continue is verified in writing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-p16
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The tax-exempt nature of some of the above payments should also be considered. ```

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-12-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Same consumer. For purposes of the definition of “simultaneous loan,” the term “same consumer” includes any consumer, as that term is defined in § 1026.2(a)(11), that enters into a loan that is a covered transaction and also enters into another loan (e.g., second-lien covered transaction or HELOC) secured by the same dwelling. Where two or more consumers enter into a legal obligation that is a covered transaction, but only one of them enters into another loan secured by the same dwelling, the “same consumer” includes the person that has entered into both legal obligations. For example, assume Consumer A and Consumer B will both enter into a legal obligation that is a covered transaction with a creditor. Immediately prior to consummation of the covered transaction, Consumer B opens a HELOC that is secured by the same dwelling with the same creditor; Consumer A is not a signatory to the HELOC. For purposes of this definition, Consumer B is the same consumer and the creditor must include the HELOC as a simultaneous loan.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-vi-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Government benefits. In verifying a consumer's income, a creditor may use a written or electronic record from a government agency of the amount of any benefit payments or awards, such as a “proof of income letter” issued by the Social Security Administration (also known as a “budget letter,” “benefits letter,” or “proof of award letter”).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-9-iv-C
interpParagraph.content: The remaining loan term as of June 1, 2016, the date of the recast, which is 27 years and nine months (333 monthly payments).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-12-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: General. Section 1026.43(b)(12) defines a simultaneous loan as another covered transaction or a home equity line of credit (HELOC) subject to § 1026.40 that will be secured by the same dwelling and made to the same consumer at or before consummation of the covered transaction, whether it is made by the same creditor or a third-party creditor. (As with all of § 1026.43, the term “dwelling” includes any real property attached to a dwelling.) For example, assume a consumer will enter into a legal obligation that is a covered transaction with Creditor A. Immediately prior to consummation of the covered transaction with Creditor A, the consumer opens a HELOC that is secured by the same dwelling with Creditor B. For purposes of this section, the loan extended by Creditor B is a simultaneous loan. See commentary to § 1026.43(c)(2)(iv) and (c)(6), discussing the requirement to consider the consumer's payment obligation on any simultaneous loan for purposes of determining the consumer's ability to repay the covered transaction subject to this section.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-9-iv-A
interpParagraph.content: The maximum loan amount of $229,251 as of June 1, 2016;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-Interp-7-ii
interpParagraph.content: Adjustable-rate mortgage with discount for three years.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-Interp-7-ii-A
interpParagraph.content: A loan in an amount of $200,000 has a 30-year loan term. The loan agreement provides for a discounted interest rate of 5 percent that is fixed for an initial period of three years, after which the interest rate will adjust annually based on a specified index plus a margin of 3 percent, subject to a 2 percent annual interest rate adjustment cap and a lifetime maximum interest rate of 9 percent. The index value in effect at consummation is 4.5 percent. The loan is consummated on March 15, 2014, and the first regular periodic payment is due May 1, 2014. The loan agreement provides that the first rate adjustment occurs on April 1, 2017 (the due date of the 36th monthly payment); the second rate adjustment occurs on April 1, 2018 (the due date of the 48th monthly payment); and the third rate adjustment occurs on April 1, 2019 (the due date of the 60th monthly payment). Under this example, the maximum interest rate during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment due is 9 percent (the lifetime interest rate cap), which applies beginning on April 1, 2018 (the due date of the 48th monthly payment). The outstanding principal balance at the end of the fourth year (after the 48th payment is credited) is $188,218.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-Interp-7-ii-B
interpParagraph.content: The transaction will meet the definition of a qualified mortgage if the creditor underwrites the loan using the monthly payment of principal and interest of $1,564 to repay the outstanding principal balance at the end of the fourth year of $188,218 over the remaining 26 years of the loan term (312 months), using the maximum interest rate during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due of 9 percent. Alternatively, the transaction will meet the definition of a qualified mortgage if the creditor underwrites the loan using the monthly payment of principal and interest of $1,609 to repay the loan amount of $200,000 over the 30-year loan term, using the maximum interest rate during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due of 9 percent.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5
paragraph.title: Seller financers; one property.
paragraph.content: Seller financers; one property. A natural <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>, estate, or trust that meets all of the following criteria is not a <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> under paragraph <ref target="1026-36-a-1" reftype="internal">(a)(1)</ref> of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-i
paragraph.content: The natural <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>, estate, or trust provides seller financing for the sale of only one property in any 12-month period to purchasers of such property, which is owned by the natural <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>, estate, or trust and serves as security for the financing.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-ii
paragraph.content: The natural <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>, estate, or trust has not constructed, or acted as a contractor for the construction of, a residence on the property in the ordinary course of business of the <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii
paragraph.content: The natural <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>, estate, or trust provides seller financing that meets the following requirements:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii-A
paragraph.content: The financing has a repayment schedule that does not result in negative amortization.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii-B
paragraph.content: The financing has a fixed rate or an adjustable rate that is adjustable after five or more years, subject to reasonable annual and lifetime limitations on interest rate increases. If the financing agreement has an adjustable rate, the rate is determined by the addition of a margin to an index rate and is subject to reasonable rate adjustment limitations. The index the adjustable rate is based on is a widely available index such as indices for U.S. Treasury securities or LIBOR.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-Interp-4-iii
interpParagraph.content: Balloon-payment mortgage with a six-year loan term; fixed interest rate. A loan provides for a fixed interest rate of 6 percent, which is below the APOR threshold for a comparable transaction, and thus, the loan is not a higher-priced covered transaction. The loan amount is $200,000, and the loan has a six-year loan term but is amortized over 30 years. The loan is consummated on March 15, 2014, and the monthly payment scheduled for the first six years following consummation is $1,199, with the first monthly payment due on May 1, 2014. The first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due end on May 1, 2019. The balloon payment of $183,995 is required on the due date of the 72nd monthly payment, which is April 1, 2020 (more than five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due). For purposes of § 1026.43(c)(2)(iii), the creditor may determine the consumer's ability to repay the loan based on the monthly payment of $1,199, and need not consider the balloon payment of $183,995 due on April 1, 2020.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-b
paragraph.content: Debts lasting less than ten months must be included if the amount of the debt affects the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s ability to pay the mortgage during the months immediately after loan closing, especially if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have limited or no cash assets after loan closing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must include the following when computing the debt to income ratios for recurring obligations:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-i
paragraph.content: Monthly housing expense; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii
paragraph.content: Additional recurring charges extending ten months or more, such as

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-a
paragraph.content: Payments on installment accounts;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-b
paragraph.content: Child support or separate maintenance payments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-c
paragraph.content: Revolving accounts; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-d
paragraph.content: Alimony.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3-iii
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-vi" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(vi)</ref> of this section, if a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> relies on a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> report to verify a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current debt obligations and a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s application <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">states</ref> a current debt obligation not shown in the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> report, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> need not independently verify such an obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-i
paragraph.content: The loan satisfies the requirements for a qualified mortgage in paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-e-2-i-A" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(i)(A)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-2-ii" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(ii)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-2-iii" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(iii)</ref>, and <ref target="1026-43-e-2-v" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(v)</ref> of this section, but without regard to the standards in appendix <ref target="1026-Q" reftype="internal">Q</ref>;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-viii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Multiple applicants. When two or more consumers apply for an extension of credit as joint obligors with primary liability on an obligation, § 1026.43(c)(2)(viii) requires a creditor to consider the credit history of all such joint applicants. If a consumer is merely a surety or guarantor, § 1026.43(c)(2)(viii) does not require a creditor to consider the credit history of such surety or guarantor. The requirements of § 1026.43(c)(2)(viii) do not affect the disclosure requirements of this part, such as, for example, §§ 1026.17(d), 1026.23(b), 1026.31(e), 1026.39(b)(3), and 1026.46(f).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Transfer three years after consummation. Under § 1026.43(f)(2)(i), if a balloon-payment qualified mortgage under § 1026.43(f)(1) is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred three years or more after consummation, the balloon-payment qualified mortgage retains its status as a qualified mortgage under § 1026.43(f)(1) following the sale. The transferee need not be eligible to originate qualified mortgages under § 1026.43(f)(1)(vi). The balloon-payment qualified mortgage will continue to be a qualified mortgage throughout its life, and the transferee, and any subsequent transferees, may invoke the presumption of compliance for qualified mortgages under § 1026.43(f)(1).

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iii-B
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives no direct or indirect <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> in connection with the charge; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> pursuant to a capital restoration plan or other action under <ref target="USC:12-1831" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 1831</ref>o, actions or instructions of any <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> acting as conservator, receiver or bankruptcy trustee, an order of a <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> or Federal governmental agency with jurisdiction to examine the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> pursuant to <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> or Federal law, or an agreement between the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> and such an agency; or

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: General. For loans that permit interest-only payments, the creditor must use the fully indexed rate or introductory rate, whichever is greater, to calculate the substantially equal, monthly payment of principal and interest that will repay the loan amount over the term of the loan remaining as of the date the loan is recast. For discussion regarding the fully indexed rate, and the meaning of “substantially equal,” see comments 43(b)(3)-1 through -5 and 43(c)(5)(i)-4, respectively. Under § 1026.43(c)(5)(ii)(B), the relevant term of the loan is the period of time that remains as of the date the loan is recast to require fully amortizing payments. For a loan on which only interest and no principal has been paid, the loan amount will be the outstanding principal balance at the time of the recast. “Loan amount” and “recast” are defined in § 1026.43(b)(5) and (b)(11), respectively. “Interest-only” and “Interest-only loan” are defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iv).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Examples. The following are examples of how to determine the consumer's repayment ability based on substantially equal, monthly payments of principal and interest under § 1026.43(c)(5)(ii)(B) (all amounts shown are rounded, and all amounts are calculated using non-rounded values):

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: Fixed-rate mortgage with interest-only payments for five years. A loan in an amount of $200,000 has a 30-year loan term. The loan agreement provides for a fixed interest rate of 7 percent, and permits interest-only payments for the first five years. The monthly payment of $1,167 scheduled for the first five years would cover only the interest due. The loan is recast on the due date of the 60th monthly payment, after which the scheduled monthly payments increase to $1,414, a monthly payment that repays the loan amount of $200,000 over the 25 years remaining as of the date the loan is recast (300 months). For purposes of § 1026.43(c)(2)(iii), the creditor must determine the consumer's ability to repay the loan based on a payment of $1,414, which is the substantially equal, monthly, fully amortizing payment that would repay $200,000 over the 25 years remaining as of the date the loan is recast using the fixed interest rate of 7 percent.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-B-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: Adjustable-rate mortgage with discount for three years and interest-only payments for five years. A loan in an amount of $200,000 has a 30-year loan term, but provides for interest-only payments for the first five years. The loan agreement provides for a discounted interest rate of 5 percent that is fixed for an initial period of three years, after which the interest rate will adjust each year based on a specified index plus a margin of 3 percent, subject to an annual interest rate adjustment cap of 2 percent. The index value in effect at consummation is 4.5 percent; the fully indexed rate is 7.5 percent (4.5 percent plus 3 percent). The monthly payments for the first three years are $833. For the fourth year, the payments are $1,167, based on an interest rate of 7 percent, calculated by adding the 2 percent annual adjustment cap to the initial rate of 5 percent. For the fifth year, the payments are $1,250, applying the fully indexed rate of 7.5 percent. These first five years of payments will cover only the interest due. The loan is recast on the due date of the 60th monthly payment, after which the scheduled monthly payments increase to $1,478, a monthly payment that will repay the loan amount of $200,000 over the remaining 25 years of the loan (300 months). For purposes of § 1026.43(c)(2)(iii), the creditor must determine the consumer's ability to repay the loan based on a monthly payment of $1,478, which is the substantially equal, monthly payment of principal and interest that would repay $200,000 over the 25 years remaining as of the date the loan is recast using the fully indexed rate of 7.5 percent.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-Interp-7-iv
interpParagraph.content: Adjustable-rate mortgage with discount for seven years.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-Interp-7-iv-A
interpParagraph.content: A loan in an amount of $200,000 has a 30-year loan term. The loan agreement provides for a discounted interest rate of 6 percent that is fixed for an initial period of seven years, after which the interest rate will adjust annually based on a specified index plus a margin of 3 percent, subject to a 2 percent annual interest rate adjustment cap. The index value in effect at consummation is 4.5 percent. The loan is consummated on March 15, 2014, and the first regular periodic payment is due May 1, 2014. Under the terms of the loan agreement, the first rate adjustment is on April 1, 2021 (the due date of the 84th monthly payment), which occurs more than five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due. Thus, the maximum interest rate under the terms of the loan during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due is 6 percent.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-Interp-7-iv-B
interpParagraph.content: The transaction will meet the definition of a qualified mortgage if the creditor underwrites the loan using the monthly payment of principal and interest of $1,199 to repay the loan amount of $200,000 over the 30-year loan term using the maximum interest rate during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due of 6 percent.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-Interp-4
interpParagraph.content: Eligible for purchase, guarantee, or insurance. To satisfy § 1026.43(e)(4)(ii), a loan need not be actually purchased or guaranteed by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac or insured or guaranteed by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, U.S. Department of Agriculture, or Rural Housing Service. Rather, § 1026.43(e)(4)(ii) requires only that the loan be eligible (i.e., meet the criteria) for such purchase, guarantee, or insurance. For example, for purposes of § 1026.43(e)(4), a creditor is not required to sell a loan to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac (or any limited-life regulatory entity succeeding the charter of either) to be a qualified mortgage; however, the loan must be eligible for purchase or guarantee by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac (or any limited-life regulatory entity succeeding the charter of either), including satisfying any requirements regarding consideration and verification of a consumer's income or assets, credit history, and debt-to-income ratio or residual income. To determine eligibility, a creditor may rely on an underwriting recommendation provided by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac's Automated Underwriting Systems (AUSs) or written guide in effect at the time. Accordingly, a covered transaction is eligible for purchase or guarantee by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac if:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-Interp-4-i
interpParagraph.content: The loan conforms to the standards set forth in the Fannie Mae Single-Family Selling Guide or the Freddie Mac Single-Family Seller/Servicer Guide; or

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-Interp-4-ii
interpParagraph.content: The loan receives one of the following recommendations from the corresponding automated underwriting system:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-Interp-4-ii-A
interpParagraph.content: An “Approve/Eligible” recommendation from Desktop Underwriter (DU); or

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-Interp-4-ii-B
interpParagraph.content: An “Accept and Eligible to Purchase” recommendation from Loan Prospector (LP).

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iii-A
paragraph.content: The charge is reasonable;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-b
paragraph.content: The table below describes the items found on IRS Form 1120 for which an adjustment must be made in order to determine adjusted business income.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-4-i-Interp-1-i
interpParagraph.content: If the consumer finances a $300 fee for a creditor-conducted appraisal and pays $400 in prepaid finance charges at closing, the amount financed under § 1026.18(b) is $9,900 ($10,000 plus the $300 appraisal fee that is paid to and financed by the creditor, less $400 in prepaid finance charges). The $300 appraisal fee paid to the creditor is added to other points and fees under § 1026.32(b)(1)(iii). It is deducted from the amount financed ($9,900) to derive a total loan amount of $9,600.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a
paragraph.content: In order to determine a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s self-employed income from a corporation the adjusted business income must:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a-i
paragraph.content: Be determined; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Multiplied by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s percentage of ownership in the business.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-6-ii
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Agreement. The creditor's agreement with a mortgage broker for purposes of § 1026.43(g)(4) may be part of another agreement with the mortgage broker, for example, a compensation agreement. Thus, the creditor need not enter into a separate agreement with the mortgage broker with respect to each covered transaction with a prepayment penalty.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-i
paragraph.title: Mortgage-related obligations.
paragraph.content: Mortgage-related obligations. For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref>, mortgage-related obligations are expected property taxes, premiums for mortgage-related insurance required by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> as set forth in § <ref target="1026-35-b-3-i" reftype="internal">1026.35(b), and </ref>similar expenses.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-ii
paragraph.title: Calculations—
paragraph.content: Calculations—

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-ii-A
paragraph.title: Monthly debt-to-income ratio.
paragraph.content: Monthly debt-to-income ratio. If a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> considers the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly debt-to-income ratio under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-vii" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(vii)</ref> of this section, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must consider the ratio of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt obligations to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly income.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-7-ii-B
paragraph.title: Monthly residual income.
paragraph.content: Monthly residual income. If a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> considers the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly residual income under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-vii" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(vii)</ref> of this section, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must consider the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s remaining income after subtracting the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt obligations from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly income.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-5-i
interpParagraph.content: A loan in an amount of $200,000 has a 30-year loan term. The loan agreement provides for a discounted introductory interest rate of 5 percent that is fixed for an initial period of two years, after which the interest rate will adjust annually based on a specified index plus a margin of 3 percentage points.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-ii
paragraph.content: Placed in an account that only the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may access.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-i
paragraph.content: Paid directly to the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D
paragraph.content: Neither the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> nor its <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> maintains an escrow account of the type described in paragraph <ref target="1026-35-b-1" reftype="internal">(b)(1)</ref> of this section for any extension of <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> secured by real property or a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or its <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> currently services, other than:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-1
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established for first-lien <ref target="1026-35-a-1" reftype="term">higher-priced mortgage loans</ref> on or after April 1, 2010, and before June 1, 2013; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-2
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> as an accommodation to distressed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> to assist such <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> in avoiding default or foreclosure.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-B
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> and its <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliates</ref> together originated 500 or fewer covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-C
paragraph.content: As of the end of the preceding calendar year, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> had total assets of less than $2,000,000,000; this asset threshold shall adjust automatically each year, based on the year-to-year change in the average of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref> Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, not seasonally adjusted, for each 12-month period ending in November, with rounding to the nearest million dollars (see comment <ref target="1026-35-b-2-iii-Interp-1-iii" reftype="internal">35(b)(2)(iii)-1.iii</ref> for the current threshold); and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> extended more than 50 percent of its total covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, on properties that are located in counties that are either “rural” or “underserved,” as set forth in paragraph (b)(2)(iv) of th<ref target="1026-35-b-2-iv" reftype="internal">is section</ref>;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Total loan amount. The term “total loan amount” is defined in § 1026.32(b)(4)(i). For an explanation of how to calculate the “total loan amount” under § 1026.43(e)(3)(i), see comment 32(b)(4)(i)-1.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Calculation of allowable points and fees. A creditor must determine which category the loan falls into based on the face amount of the note (the “loan amount” as defined in § 1026.43(b)(5)). For categories with a percentage limit, the creditor must apply the allowable points and fees percentage to the “total loan amount,” which may be different than the loan amount. A creditor must calculate the allowable amount of points and fees for a qualified mortgage as follows:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: First, the creditor must determine the “tier” into which the loan falls based on the loan amount. The loan amount is the principal amount the consumer will borrow, as reflected in the promissory note or loan contract. See § 1026.43(b)(5). For example, if the loan amount is $55,000, the loan falls into the tier for loans greater than or equal to $20,000 but less than $60,000, to which a 5 percent cap on points and fees applies. For tiers with a prescribed dollar limit on points and fees (e.g., for loans from $60,000 up to $100,000, the limit is $3,000), the creditor does not need to do any further calculations.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: Second, for tiers with a percentage limit, the creditor must determine the total loan amount based on the calculation for the total loan amount under comment 32(b)(4)(i)-1. If the loan amount is $55,000, for example, the total loan amount may be a different amount, such as $52,000.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-2-iii
interpParagraph.content: Third, the creditor must apply the percentage cap on points and fees to the total loan amount. For example, for a loan of $55,000 where the total loan amount is $52,000, the allowable points and fees are 5 percent of $52,000, or $2,600.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Sample determination of allowable points and fees.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-i
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $105,000 falls into the first points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of 3 percent of the total loan amount applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(A). Therefore, if the calculation under comment 32(b)(4)(i)-1 results in a total loan amount of $102,000, then the allowable total points and fees for this loan are 3 percent of $102,000, or $3,060.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-ii
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $75,000 falls into the second points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of $3,000 applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(B). The allowable total points and fees for this loan are $3,000, regardless of the total loan amount.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-iii
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $50,000 falls into the third points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of 5 percent of the total loan amount applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(C). Therefore, if the calculation under comment 32(b)(4)(i)-1 results in a total loan amount of $48,000, then the allowable total points and fees for this loan are 5 percent of $48,000, or $2,400.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-iv
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $15,000 falls into the fourth points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of $1,000 applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(D). The allowable total points and fees for this loan are $1,000, regardless of the total loan amount.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-3-v
interpParagraph.content: A covered transaction with a loan amount of $10,000 falls into the fifth points and fees tier, to which a points and fees cap of 8 percent of the total loan amount applies. See § 1026.43(e)(3)(i)(E). Therefore, if the calculation under comment 32(b)(4)(i)-1 results in a total loan amount of $7,000, then the allowable total points and fees for this loan are 8 percent of $7,000, or $560.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i
paragraph.content: Dual <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-36-d-2-i-C" reftype="internal">(d)(2)(i)(C)</ref> of this section, if any <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> receives <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> directly from a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> in a <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction secured by a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A-1
paragraph.content: No <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> shall receive <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref>, directly or indirectly, from any <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> other than the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> in connection with the transaction; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A-2
paragraph.content: No <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> who knows or has reason to know of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>-paid <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> to the <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> (other than the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>) shall pay any <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> to a <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref>, directly or indirectly, in connection with the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-B
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">Compensation</ref> received directly from a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> includes payments to a <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> made pursuant to an agreement between the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> and a <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> other than the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or its <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliates</ref>, under which such other <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> agrees to provide funds toward the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s costs of the transaction (including <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref>).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-C
paragraph.content: If a <ref target="1026-36-a-1-iii" reftype="term">loan originator organization</ref> receives <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> directly from a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> in connection with a transaction, the <ref target="1026-36-a-1-iii" reftype="term">loan originator organization</ref> may pay <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> to an <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref>, and the <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref> may receive <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> from the <ref target="1026-36-a-1-iii" reftype="term">loan originator organization</ref>, subject to paragraph <ref target="1026-36-d-1" reftype="internal">(d)(1)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-ii
paragraph.content: Any loss resulting from the calculation of the difference between the actual expenditures and the expense account allowance.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-1
paragraph.title: Types of Non Taxable Income.
paragraph.content: Types of Non Taxable Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2
paragraph.title: Adding Non Taxable Income to a Consumer's Gross Income.
paragraph.content: Adding Non Taxable Income to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>'s Gross Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-a
paragraph.content: The amount of continuing tax savings attributed to regular income not subject to Federal taxes may be added to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s gross income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-b
paragraph.content: The percentage of non-taxable income that may be added cannot exceed the appropriate tax rate for the income amount. Additional allowances for dependents are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-i
paragraph.content: Must document and support the amount of income grossed up for any non-taxable income source, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-ii
paragraph.content: Should use the tax rate used to calculate the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s last year's income tax.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-p23
paragraph.content: ```note Note: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is not required to file a Federal tax return, the tax rate to use is 25 percent. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing Projected Income.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Projected Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a
paragraph.content: Projected or hypothetical income is not acceptable for qualifying purposes. However, exceptions are permitted for income from the following sources:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-i
paragraph.content: Cost-of-living adjustments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Performance raises; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-iii
paragraph.content: Bonuses.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b
paragraph.content: For the above exceptions to apply, the income must be:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b-i
paragraph.content: Verified in writing by the employer; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b-ii
paragraph.content: Scheduled to begin within 60 days of loan closing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4
paragraph.title: Project Income for New Job.
paragraph.content: Project Income for New Job.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-a
