paragraph.content: Alimony, Child Support, and Maintenance Income Criteria. Alimony, child support, or maintenance income may be considered effective, if:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-1
paragraph.content: Payments are likely to be received consistently for the first three years of the mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> provides the required documentation, which includes a copy of the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-i
paragraph.content: Final divorce decree;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-ii
paragraph.content: Legal separation agreement;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-iii
paragraph.content: Court order; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-iv
paragraph.content: Voluntary payment agreement; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can provide acceptable evidence that payments have been received during the last 12 months, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-i
paragraph.content: Cancelled checks;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-ii
paragraph.content: Deposit slips;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iii
paragraph.content: Tax returns; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iv
paragraph.content: Court records.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-p13
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Periods less than 12 months may be acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> can adequately document the payer's ability and willingness to make timely payments. ii. Child support may be “grossed up” under the same provisions as non-taxable income sources. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B
paragraph.content: Investment and Trust Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1
paragraph.title: Analyzing Interest and Dividends.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Interest and Dividends.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1-a
paragraph.content: Interest and dividend income may be used as long as tax returns or account statements support a two-year receipt history. This income must be averaged over the two years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1-b
paragraph.content: Subtract any funds that are derived from these sources, and are required for the cash investment, before calculating the projected interest or dividend income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2
paragraph.title: Trust Income.
paragraph.content: Trust Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-a
paragraph.content: Income from trusts may be used if guaranteed, constant payments will continue for at least the first three years of the mortgage term.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b
paragraph.content: Required trust income documentation includes a copy of the Trust Agreement or other trustee statement, confirming the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-i
paragraph.content: Amount of the trust;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-ii
paragraph.content: Frequency of distribution; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-iii
paragraph.content: Duration of payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-c
paragraph.content: Trust account funds may be used for the required cash investment if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> provides adequate documentation that the withdrawal of funds will not negatively affect income. The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> may use funds from the trust account for the required cash investment, but the trust income used to determine repayment ability cannot be affected negatively by its use.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3
paragraph.title: Notes Receivable Income.
paragraph.content: Notes Receivable Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a
paragraph.content: In order to include notes receivable income to qualify a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, he/she must provide:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a-i
paragraph.content: A copy of the note to establish the amount and length of payment, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Evidence that these payments have been consistently received for the last 12 months through deposit slips, cancelled checks, or tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-b
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is not the original payee on the note, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must establish that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is now a holder in due course, and able to enforce the note.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-4
paragraph.title: Eligible Investment Properties.
paragraph.content: Eligible Investment Properties.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-p14
paragraph.content: Follow the steps in the table below to calculate an investment property's income or loss if the property to be subject to a mortgage is an eligible investment property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C
paragraph.content: Military, Government Agency, and Assistance Program Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1
paragraph.title: Military Income.
paragraph.content: Military Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a
paragraph.content: Military personnel not only receive base pay, butoftentimes are entitled to additional forms of pay, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-i
paragraph.content: Income from variable housing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: Clothing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: Flight or hazard pay;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iv
paragraph.content: Rations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-v
paragraph.content: Proficiency pay.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-b
paragraph.content: These types of additional pay are acceptable when analyzing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income as long as the probability of such pay to continue is verified in writing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-p16
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The tax-exempt nature of some of the above payments should also be considered. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2
paragraph.title: VA Benefits.
paragraph.content: VA Benefits.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-a
paragraph.content: Direct <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> for service-related disabilities from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives documentation from the VA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-b
paragraph.content: Education benefits used to offset education expenses are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3
paragraph.title: Government Assistance Programs.
paragraph.content: Government Assistance Programs.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-a
paragraph.content: Income received from government assistance programs is acceptable as long as the paying agency provides documentation indicating that the income is expected to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-b
paragraph.content: If the income from government assistance programs will not be received for at least three years, it may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-c
paragraph.content: Unemployment income must be documented for two years, and there must be reasonable assurance that this income will continue. This requirement may apply to seasonal employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4
paragraph.title: Mortgage Credit Certificates.
paragraph.content: Mortgage <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">Credit</ref> Certificates.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4-a
paragraph.content: If a government entity subsidizes the mortgage payments either through direct payments or tax rebates, these payments may be considered as acceptable income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4-b
paragraph.content: Either type of subsidy may be added to gross income, or used directly to offset the mortgage payment, before calculating the qualifying ratios.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5
paragraph.title: Homeownership Subsidies.
paragraph.content: Homeownership Subsidies.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-a
paragraph.content: A monthly subsidy may be treated as income, if a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is receiving subsidies under the housing choice voucher home ownership option from a public housing agency (PHA). Although continuation of the homeownership voucher subsidy beyond the first year is subject to Congressional appropriation, for the purposes of underwriting, the subsidy will be assumed to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-b
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is receiving the subsidy directly, the amount received is treated as income. The amount received may also be treated as nontaxable income and be “grossed up” by 25 percent, which means that the amount of the subsidy, plus 25 percent of that subsidy may be added to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income from employment and/or other sources.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-c
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditors</ref> may treat this subsidy as an “offset” to the monthly mortgage payment (that is, reduce the monthly mortgage payment by the amount of the home ownership assistance payment before dividing by the monthly income to determine the payment-to-income and debt-to-income ratios). The subsidy payment must not pass through the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s hands.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d
paragraph.content: The assistance payment must be:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-i
paragraph.content: Paid directly to the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-ii
paragraph.content: Placed in an account that only the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may access.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-p17
paragraph.content: ```note Note:Assistance payments made directly to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must be treated as income. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D
paragraph.content: Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1
paragraph.title: Analyzing the Stability of Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Analyzing the Stability of Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a
paragraph.content: Rent received for properties owned by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is acceptable as long as the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> can document the stability of the rental income through:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-i
paragraph.content: A current lease;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: An agreement to lease, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: A rental history over the previous 24 months that is free of unexplained gaps greater than three months (such gaps could be explained by student, seasonal, or military renters, or property rehabilitation).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-b
paragraph.content: A separate schedule of real estate is not required for rental properties as long as all properties are documented on the Uniform Residential Loan Application.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-p18
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The underwriting analysis may not consider rental income from any property being vacated by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, except under the circumstances described below. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2
paragraph.title: Rental Income From Consumer Occupied Property.
paragraph.content: Rental Income From <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref> Occupied Property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-a
paragraph.content: The rent for multiple unit property where the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> resides in one or more units and charges rent to tenants of other units may be used for qualifying purposes.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b
paragraph.content: Projected rent for the tenant-occupied units only may:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b-i
paragraph.content: Be considered gross income, only after deducting vacancy and maintenance factors, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b-ii
paragraph.content: Not be used as a direct offset to the mortgage payment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3
paragraph.title: Income from Roommates in a Single Family Property.
paragraph.content: Income from Roommates in a Single Family Property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3-a
paragraph.content: Income from roommates in a single family property occupied as the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s primary residence is not acceptable. Rental income from boarders however, is acceptable, if the boarders are related by blood, marriage, or law.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3-b
paragraph.content: The rental income may be considered effective, if shown on the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s tax return. If not on the tax return, rental income paid by the boarder may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4
paragraph.title: Documentation Required To Verify Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Documentation Required To Verify Rental Income. Analysis of the following required documentation is necessary to verify all <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> rental income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4-a
paragraph.content: IRS Form 1040 Schedule E; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4-b
paragraph.content: Current leases/rental agreements.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5
paragraph.title: Analyzing IRS Form 1040 Schedule E.
paragraph.content: Analyzing IRS Form 1040 Schedule E.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-a
paragraph.content: The IRS Form 1040 Schedule E is required to verify all rental income. Depreciation shown on Schedule E may be added back to the net income or loss.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-b
paragraph.content: Positive rental income is considered gross income for qualifying purposes, while negative income must be treated as a recurring liability.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-c
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must confirm that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> still owns each property listed, by comparing Schedule E with the real estate owned section of the URLA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6
paragraph.title: Using Current Leases To Analyze Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Using Current Leases To Analyze Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-a
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can provide a current signed lease or other rental agreement for a property that was acquired since the last income tax filing, and is not shown on Schedule E.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b
paragraph.content: In order to calculate the rental income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-i
paragraph.content: Reduce the gross rental amount by 25 percent for vacancies and maintenance;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-ii
paragraph.content: Subtract PITI and any homeowners association dues; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-iii
paragraph.content: Apply the resulting amount to income, if positive, or recurring debts, if negative.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-7
paragraph.title: Exclusion of Rental Income From Property Being Vacated by the Consumer.
paragraph.content: Exclusion of Rental Income From Property Being Vacated by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>. Underwriters may not consider any rental income from a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s principal residence that is being vacated in favor of another principal residence, except under the conditions described below:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-8
paragraph.title: Policy Exceptions Regarding the Exclusion of Rental Income From a Principal Residence Being Vacated by a Consumer.
paragraph.content: Policy Exceptions Regarding the Exclusion of Rental Income From a Principal Residence Being Vacated by a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-p19
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. This policy assures that a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> either has sufficient income to make both mortgage payments without any rentalincome, or has an equity position not likely to result in defaulting on the mortgage on the property being vacated. ii. This applies solely to a principal residence being vacated in favor of another principal residence. It does not apply to existing rental properties disclosed on the loan application and confirmed by tax returns (Schedule E of form IRS 1040). ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-p20
paragraph.content: When a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> vacates a principal residence in favor of another principal residence, the rental income, reduced by the appropriate vacancy factor, may be considered in the underwriting analysis under the circumstances listed in the table below.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E
paragraph.content: Non Taxable and Projected Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-1
paragraph.title: Types of Non Taxable Income.
paragraph.content: Types of Non Taxable Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2
paragraph.title: Adding Non Taxable Income to a Consumer's Gross Income.
paragraph.content: Adding Non Taxable Income to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>'s Gross Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-a
paragraph.content: The amount of continuing tax savings attributed to regular income not subject to Federal taxes may be added to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s gross income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-b
paragraph.content: The percentage of non-taxable income that may be added cannot exceed the appropriate tax rate for the income amount. Additional allowances for dependents are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-i
paragraph.content: Must document and support the amount of income grossed up for any non-taxable income source, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-ii
paragraph.content: Should use the tax rate used to calculate the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s last year's income tax.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-p23
paragraph.content: ```note Note: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is not required to file a Federal tax return, the tax rate to use is 25 percent. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing Projected Income.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Projected Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a
paragraph.content: Projected or hypothetical income is not acceptable for qualifying purposes. However, exceptions are permitted for income from the following sources:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-i
paragraph.content: Cost-of-living adjustments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Performance raises; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-iii
paragraph.content: Bonuses.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b
paragraph.content: For the above exceptions to apply, the income must be:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b-i
paragraph.content: Verified in writing by the employer; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b-ii
paragraph.content: Scheduled to begin within 60 days of loan closing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4
paragraph.title: Project Income for New Job.
paragraph.content: Project Income for New Job.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-a
paragraph.content: Projected income is acceptable for qualifying purposes for a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> scheduled to start a new job within 60 days of loan closing if there is a guaranteed, non-revocable contract for employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-b
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have sufficient income or cash reserves to support the mortgage payment and any other obligations between loan closing and the start of employment. Examples of this type of scenario are teachers whose contracts begin with the new school year, or physicians beginning a residency after the loan closes fall under this category.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-c
paragraph.content: The loan is not eligible for endorsement if the loan closes more than 60 days before the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> starts the new job. To be eligible for endorsement, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must obtain from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> a pay stub or other acceptable evidence indicating that he/she has started the new job.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22
paragraph.content: Certain types of regular income may not be subject to Federal tax. Such types of nontaxable income include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-a
paragraph.content: Some portion of Social Security, some Federal government employee retirement income, Railroad Retirement Benefits, and some <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> government retirement income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-b
paragraph.content: Certain types of disability and public assistance payments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-c
paragraph.content: Child support;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-d
paragraph.content: Military allowances; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-e
paragraph.content: Other income that is documented as being exempt from Federal income taxes.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-ii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Annual adjustment for inflation. The dollar amounts, including the loan amounts, in § 1026.43(e)(3)(i) will be adjusted annually on January 1 by the annual percentage change in the CPI-U that was in effect on the preceding June 1. The Bureau will publish adjustments after the June figures become available each year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-i
paragraph.content: IRS Form 2106, Employee Business Expenses, for the previous two years; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a
paragraph.content: When analyzing the probability of continued employment, <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref> must examine:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s past employment record;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Qualifications for the position;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-iii
paragraph.content: Previous training and education; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-iv
paragraph.content: The employer's confirmation of continued employment.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-vi-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Multiple applicants. When two or more consumers apply for an extension of credit as joint obligors with primary liability on an obligation, § 1026.43(c)(2)(vi) requires a creditor to consider the debt obligations of all such joint applicants. For example, if a co-applicant is repaying a student loan at the time of underwriting, the creditor complies with § 1026.43(c)(2)(vi) by considering the co-applicant's student loan obligation. If one consumer is merely a surety or guarantor, § 1026.43(c)(2)(vi) does not require a creditor to consider the debt obligations of such surety or guarantor. The requirements of § 1026.43(c)(2)(vi) do not affect the disclosure requirements of this part, such as, for example, §§ 1026.17(d), 1026.23(b), 1026.31(e), 1026.39(b)(3), and 1026.46(f).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-vi-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Consideration of current debt obligations. Section 1026.43(c)(2)(vi) requires creditors to consider a consumer's current debt obligations and any alimony or child support the consumer is required to pay. Examples of current debt obligations include student loans, automobile loans, revolving debt, and existing mortgages that will not be paid off at or before consummation. Creditors have significant flexibility to consider current debt obligations in light of attendant facts and circumstances, including that an obligation is likely to be paid off soon after consummation. For example, a creditor may take into account that an existing mortgage is likely to be paid off soon after consummation because there is an existing contract for sale of the property that secures that mortgage. Similarly, creditors should consider whether debt obligations in forbearance or deferral at the time of underwriting are likely to affect the consumer's ability to repay based on the payment for which the consumer will be liable upon expiration of the forbearance or deferral period and other relevant facts and circumstances, such as when the forbearance or deferral period will expire.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-v-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Late payment—six months prior to application. Under § 1026.43(d)(2)(v), the exemptions in § 1026.43(d)(3) apply to a covered transaction only if, during the six months immediately preceding the creditor's receipt of the consumer's written application for a refinancing, the consumer has made no payments on the non-standard mortgage more than 30 days late. (For an explanation of “written application” and how to determine the payment due date, see comments 43(d)(2)-1 and 43(d)(2)(iv)-2.) For example, assume a consumer with a non-standard mortgage applies for a refinancing on May 1, 2014. If the consumer made a payment on March 15, 2014, that was 45 days late, the requirement under § 1026.43(d)(2)(v) is not met because the consumer made a payment more than 30 days late one and one-half months prior to application. If the number of months between consummation of the non-standard mortgage and the consumer's application for the standard mortgage is six or fewer, the consumer may not have made any payment more than 30 days late on the non-standard mortgage.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-a
paragraph.content: Direct <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> for service-related disabilities from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives documentation from the VA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-b
paragraph.content: Education benefits used to offset education expenses are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-b
paragraph.content: These types of additional pay are acceptable when analyzing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income as long as the probability of such pay to continue is verified in writing.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: General. Section 1026.32(b)(1)(i) includes in the total “points and fees” items included in the finance charge under § 1026.4(a) and (b). However, certain items that may be included in the finance charge are excluded from points and fees under § 1026.32(b)(1)(i)(A) through (F). Items excluded from the finance charge under other provisions of § 1026.4 are not included in the total points and fees under § 1026.32(b)(1)(i), but may be included in points and fees under § 1026.32(b)(1)(ii) through (vi). To illustrate: A fee imposed by the creditor for an appraisal performed by an employee of the creditor meets the definition of “finance charge” under § 1026.4(a) as “any charge payable directly or indirectly by the consumer and imposed directly or indirectly by the creditor as an incident to or a condition of the extension of credit.” However, § 1026.4(c)(7) specifies that appraisal fees are not included in the finance charge. A fee imposed by the creditor for an appraisal performed by an employee of the creditor therefore would not be included in the finance charge and would not be counted in points and fees under § 1026.32(b)(1)(i). Section 1026.32(b)(1)(iii), however, expressly includes in points and fees items listed in § 1026.4(c)(7) (including appraisal fees) if the creditor receives compensation in connection with the charge. A creditor would receive compensation for an appraisal performed by its own employee. Thus, the appraisal fee in this example must be included in the calculation of points and fees.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a
paragraph.content: Military personnel not only receive base pay, butoftentimes are entitled to additional forms of pay, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-i
paragraph.content: Income from variable housing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: Clothing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: Flight or hazard pay;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iv
paragraph.content: Rations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-v
paragraph.content: Proficiency pay.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Performance raises; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-ii-Interp-4-iii
interpParagraph.content: Assume that, according to a creditor's compensation policies, the creditor awards its loan officers a bonus at the end of the year based on the number of consummated transactions originated by the loan officer during that year. Assume also that, for the first 10 transactions originated by the loan officer in a given year, no bonus is awarded; for the next 10 transactions originated by the loan officer up to 20, a bonus of $100 per transaction is awarded; and for each transaction originated after the first 20, a bonus of $200 per transaction is awarded. In this case, if, on the date the interest rate for the transaction is set, the loan officer has originated 10 or fewer transactions that year, then none of the year-end bonus is attributable to the transaction and therefore none of the bonus is included in points and fees for that transaction. If, on the date the interest rate for the transaction is set, the loan officer has originated at more than 10 but no more than 20 transactions, $100 of the bonus is attributable to the transaction and is included in points and fees for that transaction. If, on the date the interest rate for the transaction is set, the loan officer has originated more than 20 transactions, $200 of the bonus is attributable to the transaction and is included in points and fees for the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-i
paragraph.content: Cancelled checks;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4
paragraph.title: Qualified mortgage defined—special rules
paragraph.content: Qualified mortgage defined—special rules —

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i
paragraph.title: General.
paragraph.content: General. Notwithstanding paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2" reftype="internal">(e)(2)</ref> of this section, a qualified mortgage is a <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> that satisfies:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i-A
paragraph.content: The requirements of paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-e-2-i" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(i)</ref> through <ref target="1026-43-e-2-iii" reftype="internal">(iii)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i-B
paragraph.content: One or more of the criteria in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii" reftype="internal">(e)(4)(ii)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii
paragraph.title: Eligible loans.
paragraph.content: Eligible loans. A qualified mortgage under this paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-4" reftype="internal">(e)(4)</ref> must be one of the following at <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: To be purchased or guaranteed by the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation operating under the conservatorship or receivership of the Federal Housing Finance Agency pursuant to section 1367(a) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> of 1992 (<ref target="USC:12-4617" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 4617</ref>(a)); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: To be purchased or guaranteed by any limited-life regulatory entity succeeding the charter of either the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation pursuant to section 1367(i) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> of 1992 (<ref target="USC:12-4617" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 4617</ref>(i));

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be insured by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development under the National Housing <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> (<ref target="USC:12-1707" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 1707</ref> et seq.);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-C
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be guaranteed the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-D
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be guaranteed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture pursuant to <ref target="USC:42-1472" reftype="external">42 U.S.C. 1472</ref>(h); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-E
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be insured by the Rural Housing Service.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii
paragraph.title: Sunset of special rules.
paragraph.content: Sunset of special rules.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: Each respective special rule described in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii-B" reftype="internal">(e)(4)(ii)(B)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii-C" reftype="internal">(C)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii-D" reftype="internal">(D)</ref>, or <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii-E" reftype="internal">(E)</ref> of this section shall expire on the effective date of a rule issued by each respective agency pursuant to its authority under TILA section 129C(b)(3)(ii) to define a qualified mortgage.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: Unless otherwise expired under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-4-iii-A" reftype="internal">(e)(4)(iii)(A)</ref> of this section, the special rules in this paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-4" reftype="internal">(e)(4)</ref> are available only for <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transactions</ref> consummated on or before January 10, 2021.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1
paragraph.title: Safe harbor and presumption of compliance—
paragraph.content: Safe harbor and presumption of compliance—

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-i
paragraph.title: Safe harbor for transactions that are not higher-priced covered transactions.
paragraph.content: Safe harbor for transactions that are not <ref target="1026-43-b-4" reftype="term">higher-priced covered transactions</ref>. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or assignee of a qualified mortgage, as defined in paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-e-2" reftype="internal">(e)(2)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-4" reftype="internal">(e)(4)</ref>, or <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> of this section, that is not a <ref target="1026-43-b-4" reftype="term">higher-priced covered transaction</ref>, as defined in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-b-4" reftype="internal">(b)(4)</ref> of this section, complies with the repayment ability requirements of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c" reftype="internal">(c)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii
paragraph.title: Presumption of compliance for higher-priced covered transactions.
paragraph.content: Presumption of compliance for <ref target="1026-43-b-4" reftype="term">higher-priced covered transactions</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or assignee of a qualified mortgage, as defined in paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-e-2" reftype="internal">(e)(2)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-4" reftype="internal">(e)(4)</ref>, or <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> of this section, that is a <ref target="1026-43-b-4" reftype="term">higher-priced covered transaction</ref>, as defined in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-b-4" reftype="internal">(b)(4)</ref> of this section, is presumed to comply with the repayment ability requirements of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c" reftype="internal">(c)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: To rebut the presumption of compliance described in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-1-ii-A" reftype="internal">(e)(1)(ii)(A)</ref> of this section, it must be proven that, despite meeting the requirements of paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-e-2" reftype="internal">(e)(2)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-4" reftype="internal">(e)(4)</ref>, or <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> of this section, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> did not make a reasonable and good faith determination of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability at the time of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, by showing that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income, debt obligations, alimony, child support, and the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payment (including <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref>) on the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> and on any <ref target="1026-43-b-12" reftype="term">simultaneous loans</ref> of which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> was aware at <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> would leave the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> with insufficient residual income or assets other than the value of the <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> (including any real property attached to the <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>) that secures the loan with which to meet living expenses, including any recurring and material non-debt obligations of which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> was aware at the time of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-v-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Debts. Section 1026.43(e)(2)(v)(B) requires creditors to consider and verify the consumer's current debt obligations, alimony, and child support. For purposes of this requirement, the creditor must consider and verify, at a minimum, any debt or liability specified in appendix Q. A creditor may also consider and verify other debt in accordance with § 1026.43(c)(2)(vi) and (c)(3); however, such debt would not be included in the total monthly debt-to-income ratio determination required by § 1026.43(e)(2)(vi).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3
paragraph.title: Limits on points and fees for qualified mortgages.
paragraph.content: Limits on <ref target="1026-43-b-9" reftype="term">points and fees</ref> for qualified mortgages.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> is not a qualified mortgage unless the transaction's total <ref target="1026-43-b-9" reftype="term">points and fees</ref>, as defined in § <ref target="1026-32-b-1" reftype="internal">1026.32(b)(1)</ref>, do not exceed:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-A
paragraph.content: For a <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> greater than or equal to $100,000 (indexed for inflation): 3 percent of the total <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-B
paragraph.content: For a <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> greater than or equal to $60,000 (indexed for inflation) but less than $100,000 (indexed for inflation): $3,000 (indexed for inflation);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-C
paragraph.content: For a <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> greater than or equal to $20,000 (indexed for inflation) but less than $60,000 (indexed for inflation): 5 percent of the total <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-D
paragraph.content: For a <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> greater than or equal to $12,500 (indexed for inflation) but less than $20,000 (indexed for inflation): $1,000 (indexed for inflation);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-E
paragraph.content: For a <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> less than $12,500 (indexed for inflation): 8 percent of the total <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-ii
paragraph.content: The dollar amounts, including the <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amounts</ref>, in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-3-i" reftype="internal">(e)(3)(i)</ref> of this section shall be adjusted annually on January 1 by the annual percentage change in the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref> Price Index for All Urban <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref> (CPI-U) that was reported on the preceding June 1. See the official commentary to this paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-3-ii" reftype="internal">(e)(3)(ii)</ref> for the current dollar amounts.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2
paragraph.title: Qualified mortgage defined—general.
paragraph.content: Qualified mortgage defined—general. Except as provided in paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-e-4" reftype="internal">(e)(4)</ref> or <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> of this section, a qualified mortgage is a <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-i
paragraph.content: That provides for regular periodic payments that are substantially equal, except for the effect that any interest rate change after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> has on the payment in the case of an adjustable-rate or step-rate mortgage, that do not:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-i-A
paragraph.content: Result in an increase of the principal balance;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-i-B
paragraph.content: Allow the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> to defer repayment of principal, except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> of this section; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-i-C
paragraph.content: Result in a balloon payment, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-5-i" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(5)(i)</ref>, except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-ii
paragraph.content: For which the <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref> does not exceed 30 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iii
paragraph.content: For which the total <ref target="1026-43-b-9" reftype="term">points and fees</ref> payable in connection with the loan do not exceed the amounts specified in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-3" reftype="internal">(e)(3)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv
paragraph.content: For which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> underwrites the loan, taking into account the monthly payment for <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref>, using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: The maximum interest rate that may apply during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: Periodic payments of principal and interest that will repay either:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The outstanding principal balance over the remaining term of the loan as of the date the interest rate adjusts to the maximum interest rate set forth in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2-iv-A" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(iv)(A)</ref> of this section, assuming the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have made all required payments as due prior to that date; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> over the <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-v
paragraph.content: For which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> considers and verifies at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-v-A
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current or reasonably expected income or assets other than the value of the <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> (including any real property attached to the <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>) that secures the loan, in accordance with appendix <ref target="1026-Q" reftype="internal">Q</ref> and paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-c-2-i" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(i)</ref> and <ref target="1026-43-c-4" reftype="internal">(c)(4)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-v-B
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current debt obligations, alimony, and child support in accordance with appendix <ref target="1026-Q" reftype="internal">Q</ref> and paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-c-2-vi" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(vi)</ref> and <ref target="1026-43-c-3" reftype="internal">(c)(3)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi
paragraph.content: For which the ratio of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt to total monthly income at the time of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> does not exceed 43 percent. For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2-vi" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(vi)</ref>, the ratio of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt to total monthly income is determined:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-A
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2-vi-B" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(vi)(B)</ref> of this section, in accordance with the standards in appendix <ref target="1026-Q" reftype="internal">Q</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B
paragraph.content: Using the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payment on:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B-1
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>, including the monthly payment for <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref>, in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2-iv" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(iv)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-vi-B-2
paragraph.content: Any <ref target="1026-43-b-12" reftype="term">simultaneous loan</ref> that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> knows or has reason to know will be made, in accordance with paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-c-2-iv" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(iv)</ref> and <ref target="1026-43-c-6" reftype="internal">(c)(6)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing a Consumer's Employment Record.
paragraph.content: Analyzing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>'s Employment Record.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a
paragraph.content: When analyzing the probability of continued employment, <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref> must examine:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s past employment record;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Qualifications for the position;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-iii
paragraph.content: Previous training and education; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-iv
paragraph.content: The employer's confirmation of continued employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-b
paragraph.content: Favorably consider a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for a mortgage if he/she changes jobs frequently within the same line of work, but continues to advance in income or benefits. In this analysis, income stability takes precedence over job stability.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-iv-C
interpParagraph.content: The remaining loan term as of March 1, 2019, the date of the recast, which is exactly 25 years (300 monthly payments).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-10-iv-A
interpParagraph.content: The maximum loan amount of $229,219 as of March 1, 2019.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2
paragraph.title: Post-consummation transfer of balloon-payment qualified mortgage.
paragraph.content: Post-<ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> transfer of balloon-payment qualified mortgage. A balloon-payment qualified mortgage, extended pursuant to paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f-1" reftype="internal">(f)(1)</ref>, immediately loses its status as a qualified mortgage under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f-1" reftype="internal">(f)(1)</ref> if legal title to the balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> except when:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-i
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> three years or more after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> of the balloon-payment qualified mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-ii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> that satisfies the requirements of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f-1-vi" reftype="internal">(f)(1)(vi)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> pursuant to a capital restoration plan or other action under <ref target="USC:12-1831" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 1831</ref>o, actions or instructions of any <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> acting as conservator, receiver or bankruptcy trustee, an order of a <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> or Federal governmental agency with jurisdiction to examine the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> pursuant to <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> or Federal law, or an agreement between the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> and such an agency; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iv
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred pursuant to a merger of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> with another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> or acquisition of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> by another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> or of another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. Notwithstanding paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2" reftype="internal">(e)(2)</ref> of this section, a qualified mortgage may provide for a balloon payment, provided:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-i
paragraph.content: The loan satisfies the requirements for a qualified mortgage in paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-e-2-i-A" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(i)(A)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-2-ii" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(ii)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-2-iii" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(iii)</ref>, and <ref target="1026-43-e-2-v" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(v)</ref> of this section, but without regard to the standards in appendix <ref target="1026-Q" reftype="internal">Q</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-ii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> determines at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can make all of the scheduled payments under the terms of the legal obligation, as described in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f-1-iv" reftype="internal">(f)(1)(iv)</ref> of this section, together with the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payments for all <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref> and excluding the balloon payment, from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current or reasonably expected income or assets other than the <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> that secures the loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> considers at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income and verifies the debt obligations and income used to determine that ratio in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-7" reftype="internal">(c)(7)</ref> of this section, except that the calculation of the payment on the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> for purposes of determining the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt obligations in (c)(7)(i)(A) shall be determined in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref>(iv)(A) of this section, together with the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payments for all <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref> and excluding the balloon payment;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv
paragraph.content: The legal obligation provides for:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-A
paragraph.content: Scheduled payments that are substantially equal, calculated using an amortization period that does not exceed 30 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-B
paragraph.content: An interest rate that does not increase over the term of the loan; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-C
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref> of five years or longer.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-v
paragraph.content: The loan is not subject, at <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, to a commitment to be acquired by another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>, other than a <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> that satisfies the requirements of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f-1-vi" reftype="internal">(f)(1)(vi)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-vi
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> satisfies the requirements stated in § <ref target="1026-35-b-2-iii-A" reftype="internal">1026.35(b)(2)(iii)(A)</ref>, <ref target="1026-35-b-2-iii-B" reftype="internal">(B)</ref>, and <ref target="1026-35-b-2-iii-C" reftype="internal">(C)</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b
paragraph.content: If a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b-i
paragraph.content: Provides quarterly tax returns, the income analysis may include income through the period covered by the tax filings, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b-ii
paragraph.content: Is not subject to quarterly tax returns, or does not file them, then the income shown on the P&L statement may be included in the analysis, provided the income stream based on the P&L is consistent with the previous years' earnings.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-c
paragraph.content: If the P&L statements submitted for the current year show an income stream considerably greater than what is supported by the previous year's tax returns, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must base the income analysis solely on the income verified through the tax returns.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-8-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: General. Section 1026.43(b)(8) defines mortgage-related obligations, which must be considered in determining a consumer's ability to repay pursuant to § 1026.43(c). Section 1026.43(b)(8) includes, in the evaluation of mortgage-related obligations, fees and special assessments owed to a condominium, cooperative, or homeowners association. Section 1026.43(b)(8) includes ground rent and leasehold payments in the definition of mortgage-related obligations. See commentary to § 1026.43(c)(2)(v) regarding the requirement to take into account any mortgage-related obligations for purposes of determining a consumer's ability to repay.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-a
paragraph.content: When qualifying a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for a mortgage loan, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must establish the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s earnings trend from the previous two years using the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s tax returns.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iv-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Credit insurance and debt cancellation or suspension coverage. In determining points and fees for purposes of § 1026.32(b)(1), premiums paid at or before consummation for credit insurance or any debt cancellation or suspension agreement or contract are included in points and fees whether they are paid in cash or, if permitted by applicable law, financed and whether the insurance or coverage is optional or required. Such charges are also included whether the amount represents the entire premium or payment for the coverage or an initial payment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-d
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s earnings trend for the previous two years is downward and the most recent tax return or P&L is less than the prior year's tax return, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s most recent year's tax return or P&L must be used to calculate his/her income.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-b-8-Interp-4
interpParagraph.content: Mortgage insurance, guarantee, or similar charges. Section 1026.43(b)(8) includes in the evaluation of mortgage-related obligations premiums or charges protecting the creditor against the consumer's default or other credit loss. This includes all premiums or similar charges, whether denominated as mortgage insurance, guarantee insurance, or otherwise, as determined according to applicable State or Federal law. For example, monthly “private mortgage insurance” payments paid to a non-governmental entity, annual “guarantee fee” payments required by a Federal housing program, and a quarterly “mortgage insurance” payment paid to a State agency administering a housing program are all mortgage-related obligations for purposes of § 1026.43(b)(8). Section 1026.43(b)(8) includes these charges in the definition of mortgage-related obligations if the creditor requires the consumer to pay them, even if the consumer is not legally obligated to pay the charges under the terms of the insurance program. For example, if a mortgage insurance program obligates the creditor to make recurring mortgage insurance payments, and the creditor requires the consumer to reimburse the creditor for such recurring payments, the consumer's payments are mortgage-related obligations for purposes of § 1026.43(b)(8). However, if a mortgage insurance program obligates the creditor to make recurring mortgage insurance payments, and the creditor does not require the consumer to reimburse the creditor for the cost of the mortgage insurance payments, the recurring mortgage insurance payments are not mortgage-related obligations for purposes of § 1026.43(b)(8).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b
paragraph.content: Can document a two-year work history prior to an absence from employment using:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-i
paragraph.content: Traditional employment verifications; and/or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-ii
paragraph.content: Copies of IRS Form W-2s or pay stubs.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-p3
paragraph.content: ```note Note: An acceptable employment situation includes individuals who took several years off from employment to raise children, then returned to the workforce. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-c
paragraph.content: Important: Situations not meeting the criteria listed above may not be used in qualifying. Extended absence is defined as six months.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-a
paragraph.content: Is employed in the current job for six months or longer; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-ii-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: Loan originator compensation includes the dollar value of compensation, such as a bonus, commission, or award of merchandise, services, trips, or similar prizes, that is paid by a consumer or creditor to a loan originator and can be attributed to that particular transaction. The amount of compensation that can be attributed to a particular transaction is the dollar value of compensation that the loan originator will receive if the transaction is consummated. As explained in comment 32(b)(1)(ii)-3, the amount of compensation that a loan originator will receive is calculated as of the date the interest rate is set and includes compensation that is paid before, at, or after consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-iii
paragraph.content: Provide periodic training covering Federal and <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> law requirements that apply to the <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref>'s loan origination activities.

section.subject: § 1026.43 Minimum standards for transactions secured by a dwelling.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a
paragraph.title: Scope.
paragraph.content: Scope. This section applies to any <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction that is secured by a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>, as defined in § <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="internal">1026.2(a)(19)</ref>, including any real property attached to a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>, other than:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-1
paragraph.content: A home equity line of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-40" reftype="internal">1026.40</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-2
paragraph.content: A mortgage transaction secured by a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s interest in a timeshare plan, as defined in <ref target="USC:11-101" reftype="external">11 U.S.C. 101</ref>(53(D)); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-c" reftype="internal">(c)</ref> through <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-i
paragraph.content: A reverse mortgage subject to § <ref target="1026-33" reftype="internal">1026.33</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-ii
paragraph.content: A temporary or “bridge” loan with a term of 12 months or less, such as a loan to finance the purchase of a new <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> where the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> plans to sell a current <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> within 12 months or a loan to finance the initial construction of a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-iii
paragraph.content: A construction phase of 12 months or less of a construction-to-permanent loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b
paragraph.title: Definitions.
paragraph.content: Definitions. For purposes of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-1
paragraph.content: Covered transaction means a <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction that is secured by a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>, as defined in § <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="internal">1026.2(a)(19)</ref>, including any real property attached to a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>, other than a transaction exempt from coverage under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-a" reftype="internal">(a)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-2
paragraph.content: Fully amortizing payment means a periodic payment of principal and interest that will fully repay the <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> over the <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-3
paragraph.content: Fully indexed rate means the interest rate calculated using the index or formula that will apply after <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref>, as determined at the time of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, and the maximum margin that can apply at any time during the <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-4
paragraph.content: Higher-priced covered transaction means a <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> with an annual percentage rate that exceeds the average prime offer rate for a comparable transaction as of the date the interest rate is set by 1.5 or more percentage points for a first-lien <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>, or by 3.5 or more percentage points for a subordinate-lien <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-5
paragraph.content: Loan amount means the principal amount the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will borrow as reflected in the promissory note or loan contract.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-6
paragraph.content: Loan term means the period of time to repay the obligation in full.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-7
paragraph.content: Maximum loan amount means the <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> plus any increase in principal balance that results from negative amortization, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-7-v" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(7)(v)</ref>, based on the terms of the legal obligation assuming:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-7-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> makes only the minimum periodic payments for the maximum possible time, until the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must begin making <ref target="1026-43-b-2" reftype="term">fully amortizing payments</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-7-ii
paragraph.content: The maximum interest rate is reached at the earliest possible time.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-8
paragraph.content: Mortgage-related obligations mean property taxes; premiums and similar charges identified in § <ref target="1026-4-b-5" reftype="internal">1026.4(b)(5)</ref>, <ref target="1026-4-b-7" reftype="internal">(7)</ref>, <ref target="1026-4-b-8" reftype="internal">(8)</ref>, and <ref target="1026-4-b-10" reftype="internal">(10)</ref> that are required by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; fees and special assessments imposed by a condominium, cooperative, or homeowners association; ground rent; and leasehold payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-9
paragraph.content: Points and fees has the same meaning as in § <ref target="1026-32-b-1" reftype="internal">1026.32(b)(1)</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-10
paragraph.content: Prepayment penalty has the same meaning as in § <ref target="1026-32-b-6" reftype="internal">1026.32(b)(6)</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-11
paragraph.content: Recast means:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-11-i
paragraph.content: For an adjustable-rate mortgage, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-7-i" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(7)(i)</ref>, the expiration of the period during which payments based on the introductory fixed interest rate are permitted under the terms of the legal obligation;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-11-ii
paragraph.content: For an interest-only loan, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-7-iv" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(7)(iv)</ref>, the expiration of the period during which interest-only payments are permitted under the terms of the legal obligation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-11-iii
paragraph.content: For a negative amortization loan, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-7-v" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(7)(v)</ref>, the expiration of the period during which negatively amortizing payments are permitted under the terms of the legal obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-12
paragraph.content: Simultaneous loan means another <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> or home equity line of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-40" reftype="internal">1026.40</ref> that will be secured by the same <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> and made to the same <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> of the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> or, if to be made after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, will cover closing costs of the first <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13
paragraph.content: Third-party record means:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-i
paragraph.content: A document or other record prepared or reviewed by an appropriate <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> other than the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, or the mortgage broker, as defined in § <ref target="1026-36-a-2" reftype="internal">1026.36(a)(2)</ref>, or an agent of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or mortgage broker;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-ii
paragraph.content: A copy of a tax return filed with the Internal Revenue Service or a <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> taxing authority;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-iii
paragraph.content: A record the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> maintains for an account of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> held by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-b-13-iv
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is an employee of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or the mortgage broker, a document or other record maintained by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or mortgage broker regarding the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s employment status or employment income.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c
paragraph.title: Repayment ability
paragraph.content: Repayment ability —

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-1
paragraph.title: General requirement.
paragraph.content: General requirement. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> shall not make a loan that is a <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> unless the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> makes a reasonable and good faith determination at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have a reasonable ability to repay the loan according to its terms.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2
paragraph.title: Basis for determination.
paragraph.content: Basis for determination. Except as provided otherwise in paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-d" reftype="internal">(d)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e" reftype="internal">(e)</ref>, and <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> of this section, in making the repayment ability determination required under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-1" reftype="internal">(c)(1)</ref> of this section, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must consider the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current or reasonably expected income or assets, other than the value of the <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>, including any real property attached to the <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>, that secures the loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-ii
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> relies on income from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s employment in determining repayment ability, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current employment status;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-iii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payment on the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>, calculated in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-5" reftype="internal">(c)(5)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-iv
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payment on any <ref target="1026-43-b-12" reftype="term">simultaneous loan</ref> that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> knows or has reason to know will be made, calculated in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-6" reftype="internal">(c)(6)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-v
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payment for <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-vi
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current debt obligations, alimony, and child support;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-vii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-7" reftype="internal">(c)(7)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-viii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> history.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3
paragraph.title: Verification using third-party records.
paragraph.content: Verification using <ref target="1026-43-b-13" reftype="term">third-party records</ref>. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify the information that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> relies on in determining a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability under § <ref target="1026-43-c-2" reftype="internal">1026.43(c)(2)</ref> using reasonably reliable <ref target="1026-43-b-13" reftype="term">third-party records</ref>, except that:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3-i
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-i" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(i)</ref> of this section, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> relies on in accordance with § <ref target="1026-43-c-4" reftype="internal">1026.43(c)(4)</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3-ii
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-ii" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(ii)</ref> of this section, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may verify a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s employment status orally if the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> prepares a record of the information obtained orally; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-3-iii
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-vi" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(vi)</ref> of this section, if a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> relies on a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> report to verify a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current debt obligations and a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s application <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">states</ref> a current debt obligation not shown in the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> report, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> need not independently verify such an obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4
paragraph.title: Verification of income or assets.
paragraph.content: Verification of income or assets. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify the amounts of income or assets that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> relies on under § <ref target="1026-43-c-2-i" reftype="internal">1026.43(c)(2)(i)</ref> to determine a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s ability to repay a <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> using <ref target="1026-43-b-13" reftype="term">third-party records</ref> that provide reasonably reliable evidence of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may verify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income using a tax-return transcript issued by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). Examples of other records the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may use to verify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets include:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-i
paragraph.content: Copies of tax returns the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> filed with the IRS or a <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> taxing authority;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-ii
paragraph.content: IRS Form W-2s or similar IRS forms used for reporting wages or tax withholding;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-iii
paragraph.content: Payroll statements, including military Leave and Earnings Statements;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-iv
paragraph.content: Financial institution records;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-v
paragraph.content: Records from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s employer or a third party that obtained information from the employer;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-vi
paragraph.content: Records from a Federal, <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref>, or local government agency stating the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income from benefits or entitlements;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-4-vii
