paragraph.content: Part-time income received for less than two years may be included as effective income, provided that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> justifies and documents that the income is likely to continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-c
paragraph.content: Part-time income not meeting the qualifying requirements may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-p5
paragraph.content: ```note Note: For qualifying purposes, “part-time” income refers to employment taken to supplement the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income from regular employment; part-time employment is not a primary job and it is worked less than 40 hours. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5
paragraph.title: Income from Seasonal Employment.
paragraph.content: Income from Seasonal Employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a
paragraph.content: Seasonal income is considered uninterrupted, and may be used to qualify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, if the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> documents that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a-i
paragraph.content: Has worked the same job for the past two years, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a-ii
paragraph.content: Expects to be rehired the next season.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b
paragraph.content: Seasonal employment includes:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b-i
paragraph.content: Umpiring baseball games in the summer; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b-ii
paragraph.content: Working at a department store during the holiday shopping season.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6
paragraph.title: Primary Employment Less Than 40 Hour Work Week.
paragraph.content: Primary Employment Less Than 40 Hour Work Week.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6-a
paragraph.content: When a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s primary employment is less than a typical 40-hour work week, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> should evaluate the stability of that income as regular, on-going primary employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6-b
paragraph.content: Example: A registered nurse may have worked 24 hours per week for the last year. Although this job is less than the 40-hour work week, it is the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s primary employment, and should be considered effective income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7
paragraph.title: Commission Income.
paragraph.content: Commission Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a
paragraph.content: Commission income must be averaged over the previous two years. To qualify commission income, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must provide:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a-i
paragraph.content: Copies of signed tax returns for the last two years; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a-ii
paragraph.content: The most recent pay stub.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref> whose commission income was received for more than one year, but less than two years may be considered favorably if the underwriter can:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-i
paragraph.content: Document the likelihood that the income will continue, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-ii
paragraph.content: Soundly rationalize accepting the commission income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-p6
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Unreimbursed business expenses must be subtracted from gross income. ii. A commissioned <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is one who receives more than 25 percent of his/her annual income from commissions. iii. A tax transcript obtained directly from the IRS may be used in lieu of signed tax returns, and the cost of the transcript may be charged to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8
paragraph.title: Qualifying Commission Income Earned for Less Than One Year.
paragraph.content: Qualifying Commission Income Earned for Less Than One Year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8-a
paragraph.content: Commission income earned for less than one year is not considered effective income. Exceptions may be made for situations in which the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> was changed from salary to commission within a similar position with the same employer.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8-b
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> may also qualify when the portion of earnings not attributed to commissions would be sufficient to qualify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for the mortgage.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9
paragraph.title: Employer Differential Payments.
paragraph.content: Employer Differential Payments. If the employer subsidizes a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s mortgage payment through direct payments, the amount of the payments:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9-a
paragraph.content: Is considered gross income, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9-b
paragraph.content: Cannot be used to offset the mortgage payment directly, even if the employer pays the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> directly.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-10
paragraph.title: Retirement Income.
paragraph.content: Retirement Income. Retirement income must be verified from the former employer, or from Federal tax returns. If any retirement income, such as employer pensions or 401(k)'s, will cease within the first full three years of the mortgage loan, such income may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-11
paragraph.title: Social Security Income.
paragraph.content: Social Security Income. Social Security income must be verified by the Social Security Administration or on Federal tax returns. If any benefits expire within the first full three years of the loan, the income source may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12
paragraph.title: Automobile Allowances and Expense Account Payments.
paragraph.content: Automobile Allowances and Expense Account Payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-a
paragraph.content: Only the amount by which the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s automobile allowance or expense account payments exceed actual expenditures may be considered income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b
paragraph.content: To establish the amount to add to gross income, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must provide the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-i
paragraph.content: IRS Form 2106, Employee Business Expenses, for the previous two years; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-ii
paragraph.content: Employer verification that the payments will continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-c
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> uses the standard per-mile rate in calculating automobile expenses, as opposed to the actual cost method, the portion that the IRS considers depreciation may be added back to income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d
paragraph.content: Expenses that must be treated as recurring debt include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly car payment; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-ii
paragraph.content: Any loss resulting from the calculation of the difference between the actual expenditures and the expense account allowance.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-p7
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must obtain a complete copy of the current awards letter. ii. Not all Social Security income is for retirement-aged recipients; therefore, documented continuation is required. iii. Some portion of Social Security income may be “grossed up” if deemed nontaxable by the IRS. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref> Employed by a Family Owned Business.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-1
paragraph.title: Income Documentation Requirement.
paragraph.content: Income Documentation Requirement.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8
paragraph.content: In addition to normal employment verification, a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> employed by a family owned business is required to provide evidence that he/she is not an owner of the business, which may include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-a
paragraph.content: Copies of signed personal tax returns, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-b
paragraph.content: A signed copy of the corporate tax return showing ownership percentage.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-p9
paragraph.content: ```note Note:A tax transcript obtained directly from the IRS may be used in lieu of signed tax returns, and the cost of the transcript may be charged to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D
paragraph.content: General Information on Self-Employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref> and Income Analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-1
paragraph.title: Definition: Self Employed Consumer.
paragraph.content: Definition: Self Employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>. A <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> with a 25 percent or greater ownership interest in a business is considered self-employed.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2
paragraph.title: Types of Business Structures.
paragraph.content: Types of Business Structures. There are four basic types of business structures. They include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-a
paragraph.content: Sole proprietorships;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-b
paragraph.content: Corporations;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-c
paragraph.content: Limited liability or “S” corporations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-d
paragraph.content: Partnerships.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3
paragraph.title: Minimum Length of Self Employment.
paragraph.content: Minimum Length of Self Employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3-a
paragraph.content: Income from self-employment is considered stable, and effective, if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has been self-employed for two or more years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3-b
paragraph.content: Due to the high probability of failure during the first few years of a business, the requirements described in the table below are necessary for <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> who have been self-employed for less than two years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4
paragraph.title: General Documentation Requirements for Self Employed Consumers.
paragraph.content: General Documentation Requirements for Self Employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref>. Self-employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> must provide the following documentation:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-a
paragraph.content: Signed, dated individual tax returns, with all applicable tax schedules for the most recent two years;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-b
paragraph.content: For a corporation, “S” corporation, or partnership, signed copies of Federal business income tax returns for the last two years, with all applicable tax schedules;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-c
paragraph.content: Year to date profit and loss (P&L) statement and balance sheet; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-d
paragraph.content: Business <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> report for corporations and “S” corporations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5
paragraph.title: Establishing a Consumer's Earnings Trend.
paragraph.content: Establishing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>'s Earnings Trend.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-a
paragraph.content: When qualifying a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for a mortgage loan, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must establish the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s earnings trend from the previous two years using the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b
paragraph.content: If a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b-i
paragraph.content: Provides quarterly tax returns, the income analysis may include income through the period covered by the tax filings, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b-ii
paragraph.content: Is not subject to quarterly tax returns, or does not file them, then the income shown on the P&L statement may be included in the analysis, provided the income stream based on the P&L is consistent with the previous years' earnings.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-c
paragraph.content: If the P&L statements submitted for the current year show an income stream considerably greater than what is supported by the previous year's tax returns, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must base the income analysis solely on the income verified through the tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-d
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s earnings trend for the previous two years is downward and the most recent tax return or P&L is less than the prior year's tax return, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s most recent year's tax return or P&L must be used to calculate his/her income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6
paragraph.title: Analyzing the Business's Financial Strength:
paragraph.content: Analyzing the Business's Financial Strength:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a
paragraph.content: To determine if the business is expected to generate sufficient income for the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s needs, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must carefully analyze the business's financial strength, including the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a-i
paragraph.content: Source of the business's income;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a-ii
paragraph.content: General economic outlook for similar businesses in the area.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-b
paragraph.content: Annual earnings that are stable or increasing are acceptable, while businesses that show a significant decline in income over the analysis period are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Individual Tax Returns (IRS Form 1040).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E-1
paragraph.title: General Policy on Adjusting Income Based on a Review of IRS Form 1040.
paragraph.content: General Policy on Adjusting Income Based on a Review of IRS Form 1040. The amount shown on a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s IRS Form 1040 as adjusted gross income must either be increased or decreased based on the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>'s analysis of the individual tax return and any related tax schedules.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E-2
paragraph.title: Guidelines for Analyzing IRS Form 1040.
paragraph.content: Guidelines for Analyzing IRS Form 1040. The table below contains guidelines for analyzing IRS Form 1040:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Corporate Tax Returns (IRS Form 1120).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-1
paragraph.title: Description: Corporation.
paragraph.content: Description: Corporation. A corporation is a <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref>-chartered business owned by its stockholders.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2
paragraph.title: Need To Obtain Consumer Percentage of Ownership Information.
paragraph.content: Need To Obtain <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref> Percentage of Ownership Information.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a
paragraph.content: Corporate <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> to the officers, generally in proportion to the percentage of ownership, is shown on the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a-i
paragraph.content: Corporate tax return IRS Form 1120; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a-ii
paragraph.content: Individual tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-b
paragraph.content: When a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s percentage of ownership does not appear on the tax returns, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must obtain the information from the corporation's accountant, along with evidence that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has the right to any <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing Corporate Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Corporate Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a
paragraph.content: In order to determine a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s self-employed income from a corporation the adjusted business income must:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a-i
paragraph.content: Be determined; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Multiplied by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s percentage of ownership in the business.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-b
paragraph.content: The table below describes the items found on IRS Form 1120 for which an adjustment must be made in order to determine adjusted business income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: “S” Corporation Tax Returns (IRS Form 1120S).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1
paragraph.title: Description: “S” Corporation.
paragraph.content: Description: “S” Corporation.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1-a
paragraph.content: An “S” corporation is generally a small, start-up business, with gains and losses passed to stockholders in proportion to each stockholder's percentage of business ownership.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1-b
paragraph.content: Income for owners of “S” corporations comes from IRS Form W-2 wages, and is taxed at the individual rate. The IRS Form 1120S, <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">Compensation</ref> of Officers line item is transferred to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s individual IRS Form 1040.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2
paragraph.title: Analyzing “S” Corporation Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing “S” Corporation Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-a
paragraph.content: “S” corporation depreciation and depletion may be added back to income in proportion to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s share of the corporation's income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-b
paragraph.content: In addition, the income must also be reduced proportionately by the total obligations payable by the corporation in less than one year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-c
paragraph.content: Important: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s withdrawal of cash from the corporation may have a severe negative impact on the corporation's ability to continue operating, and must be considered in the income analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Partnership Tax Returns (IRS Form 1065).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1
paragraph.title: Description: Partnership.
paragraph.content: Description: Partnership.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1-a
paragraph.content: A partnership is formed when two or more individuals form a business, and share in profits, losses, and responsibility for running the company.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1-b
paragraph.content: Each partner pays taxes on his/her proportionate share of the partnership's net income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2
paragraph.title: Analyzing Partnership Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Partnership Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-a
paragraph.content: Both general and limited partnerships report income on IRS Form 1065, and the partners' share of income is carried over to Schedule E of IRS Form 1040.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-b
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must review IRS Form 1065 to assess the viability of the business. Both depreciation and depletion may be added back to the income in proportion to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s share of income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-c
paragraph.content: Income must also be reduced proportionately by the total obligations payable by the partnership in less than one year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-d
paragraph.content: Important: Cash withdrawals from the partnership may have a severe negative impact on the partnership's ability to continue operating, and must be considered in the income analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A
paragraph.content: Alimony, Child Support, and Maintenance Income Criteria. Alimony, child support, or maintenance income may be considered effective, if:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-1
paragraph.content: Payments are likely to be received consistently for the first three years of the mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> provides the required documentation, which includes a copy of the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-i
paragraph.content: Final divorce decree;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-ii
paragraph.content: Legal separation agreement;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-iii
paragraph.content: Court order; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-iv
paragraph.content: Voluntary payment agreement; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can provide acceptable evidence that payments have been received during the last 12 months, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-i
paragraph.content: Cancelled checks;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-ii
paragraph.content: Deposit slips;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iii
paragraph.content: Tax returns; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iv
paragraph.content: Court records.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-p13
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Periods less than 12 months may be acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> can adequately document the payer's ability and willingness to make timely payments. ii. Child support may be “grossed up” under the same provisions as non-taxable income sources. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B
paragraph.content: Investment and Trust Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1
paragraph.title: Analyzing Interest and Dividends.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Interest and Dividends.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1-a
paragraph.content: Interest and dividend income may be used as long as tax returns or account statements support a two-year receipt history. This income must be averaged over the two years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1-b
paragraph.content: Subtract any funds that are derived from these sources, and are required for the cash investment, before calculating the projected interest or dividend income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2
paragraph.title: Trust Income.
paragraph.content: Trust Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-a
paragraph.content: Income from trusts may be used if guaranteed, constant payments will continue for at least the first three years of the mortgage term.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b
paragraph.content: Required trust income documentation includes a copy of the Trust Agreement or other trustee statement, confirming the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-i
paragraph.content: Amount of the trust;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-ii
paragraph.content: Frequency of distribution; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-iii
paragraph.content: Duration of payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-c
paragraph.content: Trust account funds may be used for the required cash investment if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> provides adequate documentation that the withdrawal of funds will not negatively affect income. The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> may use funds from the trust account for the required cash investment, but the trust income used to determine repayment ability cannot be affected negatively by its use.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3
paragraph.title: Notes Receivable Income.
paragraph.content: Notes Receivable Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a
paragraph.content: In order to include notes receivable income to qualify a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, he/she must provide:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a-i
paragraph.content: A copy of the note to establish the amount and length of payment, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Evidence that these payments have been consistently received for the last 12 months through deposit slips, cancelled checks, or tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-b
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is not the original payee on the note, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must establish that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is now a holder in due course, and able to enforce the note.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-4
paragraph.title: Eligible Investment Properties.
paragraph.content: Eligible Investment Properties.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-p14
paragraph.content: Follow the steps in the table below to calculate an investment property's income or loss if the property to be subject to a mortgage is an eligible investment property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C
paragraph.content: Military, Government Agency, and Assistance Program Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1
paragraph.title: Military Income.
paragraph.content: Military Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a
paragraph.content: Military personnel not only receive base pay, butoftentimes are entitled to additional forms of pay, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-i
paragraph.content: Income from variable housing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: Clothing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: Flight or hazard pay;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iv
paragraph.content: Rations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-v
paragraph.content: Proficiency pay.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-b
paragraph.content: These types of additional pay are acceptable when analyzing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income as long as the probability of such pay to continue is verified in writing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-p16
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The tax-exempt nature of some of the above payments should also be considered. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2
paragraph.title: VA Benefits.
paragraph.content: VA Benefits.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-a
paragraph.content: Direct <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> for service-related disabilities from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives documentation from the VA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-b
paragraph.content: Education benefits used to offset education expenses are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3
paragraph.title: Government Assistance Programs.
paragraph.content: Government Assistance Programs.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-a
paragraph.content: Income received from government assistance programs is acceptable as long as the paying agency provides documentation indicating that the income is expected to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-b
paragraph.content: If the income from government assistance programs will not be received for at least three years, it may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-c
paragraph.content: Unemployment income must be documented for two years, and there must be reasonable assurance that this income will continue. This requirement may apply to seasonal employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4
paragraph.title: Mortgage Credit Certificates.
paragraph.content: Mortgage <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">Credit</ref> Certificates.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4-a
paragraph.content: If a government entity subsidizes the mortgage payments either through direct payments or tax rebates, these payments may be considered as acceptable income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-4-b
paragraph.content: Either type of subsidy may be added to gross income, or used directly to offset the mortgage payment, before calculating the qualifying ratios.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5
paragraph.title: Homeownership Subsidies.
paragraph.content: Homeownership Subsidies.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-a
paragraph.content: A monthly subsidy may be treated as income, if a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is receiving subsidies under the housing choice voucher home ownership option from a public housing agency (PHA). Although continuation of the homeownership voucher subsidy beyond the first year is subject to Congressional appropriation, for the purposes of underwriting, the subsidy will be assumed to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-b
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is receiving the subsidy directly, the amount received is treated as income. The amount received may also be treated as nontaxable income and be “grossed up” by 25 percent, which means that the amount of the subsidy, plus 25 percent of that subsidy may be added to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income from employment and/or other sources.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-c
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditors</ref> may treat this subsidy as an “offset” to the monthly mortgage payment (that is, reduce the monthly mortgage payment by the amount of the home ownership assistance payment before dividing by the monthly income to determine the payment-to-income and debt-to-income ratios). The subsidy payment must not pass through the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s hands.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d
paragraph.content: The assistance payment must be:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-i
paragraph.content: Paid directly to the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-ii
paragraph.content: Placed in an account that only the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may access.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-5-d-p17
paragraph.content: ```note Note:Assistance payments made directly to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must be treated as income. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D
paragraph.content: Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1
paragraph.title: Analyzing the Stability of Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Analyzing the Stability of Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a
paragraph.content: Rent received for properties owned by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is acceptable as long as the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> can document the stability of the rental income through:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-i
paragraph.content: A current lease;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: An agreement to lease, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: A rental history over the previous 24 months that is free of unexplained gaps greater than three months (such gaps could be explained by student, seasonal, or military renters, or property rehabilitation).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-b
paragraph.content: A separate schedule of real estate is not required for rental properties as long as all properties are documented on the Uniform Residential Loan Application.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-1-p18
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The underwriting analysis may not consider rental income from any property being vacated by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, except under the circumstances described below. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2
paragraph.title: Rental Income From Consumer Occupied Property.
paragraph.content: Rental Income From <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref> Occupied Property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-a
paragraph.content: The rent for multiple unit property where the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> resides in one or more units and charges rent to tenants of other units may be used for qualifying purposes.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b
paragraph.content: Projected rent for the tenant-occupied units only may:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b-i
paragraph.content: Be considered gross income, only after deducting vacancy and maintenance factors, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-2-b-ii
paragraph.content: Not be used as a direct offset to the mortgage payment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3
paragraph.title: Income from Roommates in a Single Family Property.
paragraph.content: Income from Roommates in a Single Family Property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3-a
paragraph.content: Income from roommates in a single family property occupied as the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s primary residence is not acceptable. Rental income from boarders however, is acceptable, if the boarders are related by blood, marriage, or law.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-3-b
paragraph.content: The rental income may be considered effective, if shown on the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s tax return. If not on the tax return, rental income paid by the boarder may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4
paragraph.title: Documentation Required To Verify Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Documentation Required To Verify Rental Income. Analysis of the following required documentation is necessary to verify all <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> rental income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4-a
paragraph.content: IRS Form 1040 Schedule E; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-4-b
paragraph.content: Current leases/rental agreements.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5
paragraph.title: Analyzing IRS Form 1040 Schedule E.
paragraph.content: Analyzing IRS Form 1040 Schedule E.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-a
paragraph.content: The IRS Form 1040 Schedule E is required to verify all rental income. Depreciation shown on Schedule E may be added back to the net income or loss.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-b
paragraph.content: Positive rental income is considered gross income for qualifying purposes, while negative income must be treated as a recurring liability.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-5-c
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must confirm that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> still owns each property listed, by comparing Schedule E with the real estate owned section of the URLA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6
paragraph.title: Using Current Leases To Analyze Rental Income.
paragraph.content: Using Current Leases To Analyze Rental Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-a
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can provide a current signed lease or other rental agreement for a property that was acquired since the last income tax filing, and is not shown on Schedule E.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b
paragraph.content: In order to calculate the rental income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-i
paragraph.content: Reduce the gross rental amount by 25 percent for vacancies and maintenance;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-ii
paragraph.content: Subtract PITI and any homeowners association dues; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-6-b-iii
paragraph.content: Apply the resulting amount to income, if positive, or recurring debts, if negative.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-7
paragraph.title: Exclusion of Rental Income From Property Being Vacated by the Consumer.
paragraph.content: Exclusion of Rental Income From Property Being Vacated by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>. Underwriters may not consider any rental income from a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s principal residence that is being vacated in favor of another principal residence, except under the conditions described below:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-8
paragraph.title: Policy Exceptions Regarding the Exclusion of Rental Income From a Principal Residence Being Vacated by a Consumer.
paragraph.content: Policy Exceptions Regarding the Exclusion of Rental Income From a Principal Residence Being Vacated by a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-p19
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. This policy assures that a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> either has sufficient income to make both mortgage payments without any rentalincome, or has an equity position not likely to result in defaulting on the mortgage on the property being vacated. ii. This applies solely to a principal residence being vacated in favor of another principal residence. It does not apply to existing rental properties disclosed on the loan application and confirmed by tax returns (Schedule E of form IRS 1040). ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-D-p20
paragraph.content: When a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> vacates a principal residence in favor of another principal residence, the rental income, reduced by the appropriate vacancy factor, may be considered in the underwriting analysis under the circumstances listed in the table below.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E
paragraph.content: Non Taxable and Projected Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-1
paragraph.title: Types of Non Taxable Income.
paragraph.content: Types of Non Taxable Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2
paragraph.title: Adding Non Taxable Income to a Consumer's Gross Income.
paragraph.content: Adding Non Taxable Income to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>'s Gross Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-a
paragraph.content: The amount of continuing tax savings attributed to regular income not subject to Federal taxes may be added to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s gross income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-b
paragraph.content: The percentage of non-taxable income that may be added cannot exceed the appropriate tax rate for the income amount. Additional allowances for dependents are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-i
paragraph.content: Must document and support the amount of income grossed up for any non-taxable income source, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-ii
paragraph.content: Should use the tax rate used to calculate the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s last year's income tax.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-2-c-p23
paragraph.content: ```note Note: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is not required to file a Federal tax return, the tax rate to use is 25 percent. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing Projected Income.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Projected Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a
paragraph.content: Projected or hypothetical income is not acceptable for qualifying purposes. However, exceptions are permitted for income from the following sources:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-i
paragraph.content: Cost-of-living adjustments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Performance raises; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-a-iii
paragraph.content: Bonuses.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b
paragraph.content: For the above exceptions to apply, the income must be:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b-i
paragraph.content: Verified in writing by the employer; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-3-b-ii
paragraph.content: Scheduled to begin within 60 days of loan closing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4
paragraph.title: Project Income for New Job.
paragraph.content: Project Income for New Job.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-a
paragraph.content: Projected income is acceptable for qualifying purposes for a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> scheduled to start a new job within 60 days of loan closing if there is a guaranteed, non-revocable contract for employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-b
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have sufficient income or cash reserves to support the mortgage payment and any other obligations between loan closing and the start of employment. Examples of this type of scenario are teachers whose contracts begin with the new school year, or physicians beginning a residency after the loan closes fall under this category.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-4-c
paragraph.content: The loan is not eligible for endorsement if the loan closes more than 60 days before the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> starts the new job. To be eligible for endorsement, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must obtain from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> a pay stub or other acceptable evidence indicating that he/she has started the new job.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22
paragraph.content: Certain types of regular income may not be subject to Federal tax. Such types of nontaxable income include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-a
paragraph.content: Some portion of Social Security, some Federal government employee retirement income, Railroad Retirement Benefits, and some <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> government retirement income:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-b
paragraph.content: Certain types of disability and public assistance payments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-c
paragraph.content: Child support;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-d
paragraph.content: Military allowances; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-E-p22-e
paragraph.content: Other income that is documented as being exempt from Federal income taxes.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1
paragraph.title: Types of Recurring Obligation.
paragraph.content: Types of Recurring Obligation. Recurring obligations include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-a
paragraph.content: All installment loans;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-b
paragraph.content: Revolving charge accounts;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-c
paragraph.content: Real estate loans;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-d
paragraph.content: Alimony;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-e
paragraph.content: Child support; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-1-f
paragraph.content: Other continuing obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2
paragraph.title: Debt to Income Ratio Computation for Recurring Obligations.
paragraph.content: Debt to Income Ratio Computation for Recurring Obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must include the following when computing the debt to income ratios for recurring obligations:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-i
paragraph.content: Monthly housing expense; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii
paragraph.content: Additional recurring charges extending ten months or more, such as

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-a
paragraph.content: Payments on installment accounts;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-b
paragraph.content: Child support or separate maintenance payments;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-c
paragraph.content: Revolving accounts; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-a-ii-d
paragraph.content: Alimony.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-b
paragraph.content: Debts lasting less than ten months must be included if the amount of the debt affects the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s ability to pay the mortgage during the months immediately after loan closing, especially if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have limited or no cash assets after loan closing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-2-p24
paragraph.content: ```note Note:Monthly payments on revolving or open-ended accounts, regardless of the balance, are counted as a liability for qualifying purposes even if the account appears likely to be paid off within 10 months or less. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-3
paragraph.title: Revolving Account Monthly Payment Calculation.
paragraph.content: Revolving Account Monthly Payment Calculation. If the <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> report shows any revolving accounts with an outstanding balance but no specific minimum monthly payment, the payment must be calculated as the greater of:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-3-a
paragraph.content: 5 percent of the balance; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-3-p25
paragraph.content: ```note Note: If the actual monthly payment is documented from the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> obtains a copy of the current statement reflecting the monthly payment, that amount may be used for qualifying purposes. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h3-4
paragraph.title: Reduction of Alimony Payment for Qualifying Ratio Calculation.
paragraph.content: Reduction of Alimony Payment for Qualifying Ratio Calculation. Since there are tax consequences of alimony payments, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may choose to treat the monthly alimony obligation as a reduction from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s gross income when calculating qualifying ratios, rather than treating it as a monthly obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-1
paragraph.title: Definition: Contingent Liability.
paragraph.content: Definition: Contingent Liability. A contingent liability exists when an individual is held responsible for payment of a debt if another party, jointly or severally obligated, defaults on the payment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-2
paragraph.title: Application of Contingent Liability Policies.
paragraph.content: Application of Contingent Liability Policies. The contingent liability policies described in this topic apply unless the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can provide conclusive evidence from the debt holder that there is no possibility that the debt holder will pursue debt collection against him/her should the other party default.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-3
paragraph.title: Contingent Liability on Mortgage Assumptions.
paragraph.content: Contingent Liability on Mortgage Assumptions. Contingent liability must be considered when the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> remains obligated on an outstanding FHA-insured, VA-guaranteed, or conventional mortgage secured by property that:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-3-a
paragraph.content: Has been sold or traded within the last 12 months without a release of liability, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-3-b
paragraph.content: Is to be sold on assumption without a release of liability being obtained.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-4
paragraph.title: Exemption From Contingent Liability Policy on Mortgage Assumptions.
paragraph.content: Exemption From Contingent Liability Policy on Mortgage Assumptions. When a mortgage is assumed, contingent liabilities need not be considered if the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-4-a
paragraph.content: Originating <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> of the mortgage being underwritten obtains, from the servicer of the assumed loan, a payment history showing that the mortgage has been current during the previous 12 months, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-4-b
paragraph.content: Value of the property, as established by an appraisal or the sales price on the HUD-1 Settlement Statement from the sale of the property, results in a loan-to-value (LTV) ratio of 75 percent or less.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5
paragraph.title: Contingent Liability on Cosigned Obligations.
paragraph.content: Contingent Liability on Cosigned Obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a
paragraph.content: Contingent liability applies, and the debt must be included in the underwriting analysis, if an individual applying for a mortgage is a cosigner/co-obligor on:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a-i
paragraph.content: A car loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a-ii
paragraph.content: A student loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a-iii
paragraph.content: A mortgage; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-a-iv
paragraph.content: Any other obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h4-5-b
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> obtains documented proof that the primary obligor has been making regular payments during the previous 12 months, and does not have a history of delinquent payments on the loan during that time, the payment does not have to be included in the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly obligations.

appendixSection.label: 1026-Q-h5
appendixSection.subject: V. Consumer Liabilities: Projected Obligations and Obligations Not Considered Debt

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-1
paragraph.title: Projected Obligations.
paragraph.content: Projected Obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-1-a
paragraph.content: Debt payments, such as a student loan or balloon-payment note scheduled to begin or come due within 12 months of the mortgage loan closing, must be included by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> as anticipated monthly obligations during the underwriting analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-1-b
paragraph.content: Debt payments do not have to be classified as projected obligations if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> provides written evidence that the debt will be deferred to a period outside the 12-month timeframe.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-1-c
paragraph.content: Balloon-payment notes that come due within one year of loan closing must be considered in the underwriting analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2
paragraph.title: Obligations Not Considered Debt.
paragraph.content: Obligations Not Considered Debt. Obligations not considered debt, and therefore not subtracted from gross income, include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-a
paragraph.content: Federal, <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref>, and local taxes;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-b
paragraph.content: Federal Insurance Contributions <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> (FICA) or other retirement contributions, such as 401(k) accounts (including repayment of debt secured by these funds):

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-c
paragraph.content: Commuting costs;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-d
paragraph.content: Union dues;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-e
paragraph.content: Open accounts with zero balances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-f
paragraph.content: Automatic deductions to savings accounts;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-g
paragraph.content: Child care; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h5-2-h
paragraph.content: Voluntary deductions.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-p1-p1
paragraph.content: Section 1026.43(e)(2)(vi) provides that, to satisfy the requirements for a qualified mortgage under § 1026.43(e)(2), the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt to total monthly income at the time of consummation cannot exceed 43 percent. Section 1026.43(e)(2)(vi)(A) requires the creditor to calculate the ratio of the consumer's total monthly debt to total monthly income using the following standards, with additional requirements for calculating debt and income appearing in § 1026.43(e)(2)(vi)(B).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-Interp-4-ii
interpParagraph.content: Second, the payment calculation must be based on substantially equal monthly payments of principal and interest that will fully repay the outstanding principal balance over the term of the loan remaining as of the date the loan is recast. Thus, in the example above, the creditor must assume a loan term of 28 years (336 monthly payments).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-E-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Average prime offer rate. The average prime offer rate for purposes of paragraph (b)(1)(i)(E) of this section is the average prime offer rate that applies to a comparable transaction as of the date the discounted interest rate for the transaction is set. For the meaning of “comparable transaction,” refer to comment 35(a)(2)-2. The table of average prime offer rates published by the Bureau indicates how to identify the comparable transaction. See comment 35(a)(2)-2.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-Interp-5-i
interpParagraph.content: The outstanding principal balance as of the earliest date the maximum interest rate during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due can take effect under the terms of the legal obligation, over the remaining term of the loan. To illustrate, assume a loan in an amount of $200,000 has a 30-year loan term. The loan agreement provides for a discounted interest rate of 5 percent that is fixed for an initial period of three years, measured from the first day of the first full calendar month following consummation, after which the interest rate will adjust annually based on a specified index plus a margin of 3 percent, subject to a 2 percent annual interest rate adjustment cap and a lifetime maximum interest rate of 9 percent. The index value in effect at consummation equals 4.5 percent. Assuming the interest rate increases after consummation as quickly as possible, the rate adjustment to the lifetime maximum interest rate of 9 percent occurs on the due date of the 48th monthly payment. The outstanding principal balance on the loan at the end of the fourth year (after the 48th monthly payment is credited) is $188,218. The creditor will meet the definition of qualified mortgage if it underwrites the covered transaction using the monthly payment of principal and interest of $1,564 to repay the outstanding principal balance of $188,218 over the remaining 26 years of the loan term (312 months) using the maximum interest rate during the first five years of 9 percent; or

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-6-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Scope. In determining the consumer's repayment ability for a covered transaction under § 1026.43(c)(2)(iii), a creditor must include consideration of any simultaneous loan which it knows, or has reason to know, will be made at or before consummation of the covered transaction. For a discussion of the standard “knows or has reason to know,” see comment 43(c)(2)(iv)-2. For the meaning of the term “simultaneous loan,” see § 1026.43(b)(12).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-6-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Payment calculation—covered transaction. For a simultaneous loan that is a covered transaction, as that term is defined under § 1026.43(b)(1), a creditor must determine a consumer's ability to repay the monthly payment obligation for a simultaneous loan as set forth in § 1026.43(c)(5), taking into account any mortgage-related obligations required to be considered under § 1026.43(c)(2)(v). For the meaning of the term “mortgage-related obligations,” see § 1026.43(b)(8).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-6-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Payment calculation—home equity line of credit. For a simultaneous loan that is a home equity line of credit subject to § 1026.40, the creditor must consider the periodic payment required under the terms of the plan when assessing the consumer's ability to repay the covered transaction secured by the same dwelling as the simultaneous loan. Under § 1026.43(c)(6)(ii), a creditor must determine the periodic payment required under the terms of the plan by considering the actual amount of credit to be drawn by the consumer at consummation of the covered transaction. The amount to be drawn is the amount requested by the consumer; when the amount requested will be disbursed, or actual receipt of funds, is not determinative. Any additional draw against the line of credit that the creditor of the covered transaction does not know or have reason to know about before or during underwriting need not be considered in relation to ability to repay. For example, where the creditor's policies and procedures require the source of down payment to be verified, and the creditor verifies that a simultaneous loan that is a HELOC will provide the source of down payment for the first-lien covered transaction, the creditor must consider the periodic payment on the HELOC by assuming the amount drawn is at least the down payment amount. In general, a creditor should determine the periodic payment based on guidance in the commentary to § 1026.40(d)(5) (discussing payment terms).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: Assume a loan that provides for regular monthly payments and a balloon payment due at the end of a six-year loan term. The loan is consummated on August 15, 2014, and the first monthly payment is due on October 1, 2014. The first five years after the first monthly payment end on October 1, 2019. The balloon payment must be made on the due date of the 72nd monthly payment, which is September 1, 2020. For purposes of determining the consumer's ability to repay the loan under § 1026.43(c)(2)(iii), the creditor need not consider the balloon payment that is due on September 1, 2020.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: First, the creditor must determine the “tier” into which the loan falls based on the loan amount. The loan amount is the principal amount the consumer will borrow, as reflected in the promissory note or loan contract. See § 1026.43(b)(5). For example, if the loan amount is $55,000, the loan falls into the tier for loans greater than or equal to $20,000 but less than $60,000, to which a 5 percent cap on points and fees applies. For tiers with a prescribed dollar limit on points and fees (e.g., for loans from $60,000 up to $100,000, the limit is $3,000), the creditor does not need to do any further calculations.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Interest-only payments. A mortgage that only requires the payment of accrued interest each month does not meet the requirements of § 1026.43(f)(1)(iv)(A).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iii
paragraph.content: Tax returns; or

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-c-1-Interp-1-ii-B-4
interpParagraph.content: The creditor disregarded evidence that the underwriting standards it used are not effective at determining consumers' repayment ability;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12
paragraph.title: Automobile Allowances and Expense Account Payments.
paragraph.content: Automobile Allowances and Expense Account Payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-a
paragraph.content: Only the amount by which the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s automobile allowance or expense account payments exceed actual expenditures may be considered income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b
paragraph.content: To establish the amount to add to gross income, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must provide the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-i
paragraph.content: IRS Form 2106, Employee Business Expenses, for the previous two years; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-ii
paragraph.content: Employer verification that the payments will continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-c
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> uses the standard per-mile rate in calculating automobile expenses, as opposed to the actual cost method, the portion that the IRS considers depreciation may be added back to income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d
paragraph.content: Expenses that must be treated as recurring debt include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly car payment; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-ii
paragraph.content: Any loss resulting from the calculation of the difference between the actual expenditures and the expense account allowance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-vi-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Non-standard mortgage loan made in accordance with ability-to-repay or qualified mortgage requirements. For non-standard mortgages that are consummated on or after January 10, 2014, § 1026.43(d)(2)(vi) provides that the refinancing provisions set forth in § 1026.43(d) apply only if the non-standard mortgage was made in accordance with the requirements of § 1026.43(c) or (e), as applicable. For example, if a creditor originated a non-standard mortgage on or after January 10, 2014 that did not comply with the requirements of § 1026.43(c) and was not a qualified mortgage pursuant to § 1026.43(e), § 1026.43(d) would not apply to the refinancing of the non-standard mortgage loan into a standard mortgage loan. However, § 1026.43(d) applies to the refinancing of a non-standard mortgage loan into a standard mortgage loan, regardless of whether the non-standard mortgage loan was made in compliance with § 1026.43(c) or (e), if the non-standard mortgage loan was consummated prior to January 10, 2014.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-10
paragraph.title: Retirement Income.
paragraph.content: Retirement Income. Retirement income must be verified from the former employer, or from Federal tax returns. If any retirement income, such as employer pensions or 401(k)'s, will cease within the first full three years of the mortgage loan, such income may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-11
paragraph.title: Social Security Income.
paragraph.content: Social Security Income. Social Security income must be verified by the Social Security Administration or on Federal tax returns. If any benefits expire within the first full three years of the loan, the income source may not be used in qualifying.
